sections._videoScript:
Friends, I want to welcome you to something that could genuinely change the way you see the church, your community, and your own calling. This is the mDNA course — and over the next eight weeks, we are going to rediscover the genetic code of apostolic movements together.

But before we get into the content, I need to tell you what this course is *not*. This is not an information course. You will not simply consume ideas and move on with your life unchanged. If all you wanted was information, I would hand you a book and say, "Go in peace." A book can transfer information. A course exists because something needs to happen that a book cannot do — and that something is *formation*. We are here for transformation, not just education.

So here is my promise to you: over these eight weeks, we will do more than learn concepts. We will practice. We will reflect. We will experiment in the real world. And we will do it together — because formation never happens in isolation. It happens in community, and specifically in the kind of community that forms when people are on a shared journey toward something that matters.

Let me tell you why this particular content matters right now.

About fifteen years ago, I attended a seminar where a speaker asked a simple question: "How many Christians were there in the year AD 100?" The answer? As few as 25,000. Then he asked: "How many by AD 310?" Up to 20 million. And then he asked the question that has haunted me ever since: "How do you account for the fact that a tiny, persecuted Jewish sect became the most significant religious force in the Roman Empire in two centuries?"

That question sent me on a decades-long quest. And what I found — what I believe the Lord revealed — is that there is a power lying hidden at the very heart of God's people. A set of primal energies that have driven every significant Jesus movement in history. I came to call this Apostolic Genius, and the elements that compose it I call mDNA — Missional DNA.

Here is the extraordinary thing: this is not something we need to *invent*. It is something we need to *remember*. The feedback I receive most often from readers is, "I feel like I already knew this, I just couldn't articulate it." And every time I hear that, I think: *Yes. That is exactly the point.* The Spirit is once again brooding over the church, calling us back to what we have always carried within us.

So what is mDNA? Think of biological DNA — it is found in every cell, it carries the vital information for the organism, and it has the remarkable capacity to reproduce itself. What DNA does for biological systems, mDNA does for ecclesial ones. There are six elements, and they are readily discernible in every authentic Christian movement — from the early church to the Chinese underground church to the Methodist revolution:

**Jesus Is Lord** — the absolute center. Everything flows from this confession. It is both the simplest and the most radical claim we can make.

**Disciple-Making** — the essential practice. Movements grow only in proportion to their capacity to make disciples. No disciples, no movement.

**Missional-Incarnational Impulse** — the twin dynamic of going out and going deep. Sent into the world like Jesus was sent, and embedding ourselves incarnationally in culture and context.

**APEST Culture** — the fivefold intelligence. Apostle, Prophet, Evangelist, Shepherd, Teacher — the distributed ministry system Christ gave for the maturity and mission of his body.

**Organic Systems** — movemental structures. Simple, reproducible, networked patterns that enable multiplication rather than mere addition.

**Communitas** — liminal community. The deep bond that forms when people share a dangerous journey together. Not community as we normally conceive it, but the extraordinary togetherness that emerges from shared mission and risk.

Each of these is powerful on its own. But here is what you must understand: it is the whole system that creates Apostolic Genius, not any single element. There are no silver bullets — but there is a silver imagination that emerges when all six elements come together. And the weakest element limits the health of the entire system, the way the shortest stave of a barrel limits how much water it can hold.

Now let me tell you about how we will journey together.

Each week, we will focus on one element of mDNA. You will engage with a main reading, reflect through guided questions, and undertake field experiments — real-world, observable practices in your own context. You will also engage with your cohort through structured discussion. And every week opens and closes with a moment of worship and devotion, because this is not merely an intellectual exercise. We are placing ourselves under the lordship of Jesus and asking the Spirit to form us.

Week 0 — this week — is your foundation. You will take a baseline assessment that helps you identify where you are on the mDNA journey and where your growth edges lie. You will introduce yourself to your cohort. And you will begin to map the context where you will apply what you learn.

I want to say something directly to you: you are here because God has placed something in you that the world desperately needs. The church you lead, the community you serve, the people you walk alongside — they carry within them the same latent potencies that energized the early Christians and the Chinese underground church. Apostolic Genius lies dormant in you, in me, and in every local church that seeks to follow Jesus faithfully.

We have simply forgotten how to access it.

These eight weeks are about remembering. Not learning something foreign, but recovering something ancient. Not importing a new program, but reactivating the genetic code that was always there.

So welcome. I am genuinely glad you are here. Introduce yourself to the others in your cohort this week. Tell them where you are, what you lead, and what brought you to this moment. Because from this point on, we journey together.

Let's begin.

sections.reading:
We stand at a remarkable crossroads. The Western church finds itself in a moment that is simultaneously a crisis and an invitation — a moment that, if we have the courage to read it rightly, could become the seedbed for the most significant renewal we have seen in centuries. But to step into that future, we need to recover something the church has carried within itself from the beginning. Something ancient, potent, and largely forgotten.

This course is about that recovery.

Over the next eight weeks, we will explore what I call **mDNA — Missional DNA** — the six-element genetic code that has driven every significant Jesus movement in recorded history. From the explosive growth of the early church (25,000 believers in AD 100 to 20 million by AD 310) to the staggering multiplication of the Chinese underground church (2 million to over 120 million in seventy years under severe persecution), the same dynamics appear again and again. They are not accidental. They are not cultural. They are the deep architecture of how God moves his people into the world.

The claim of this course — and it is a bold one — is that **the church Jesus started already has everything in it to get its job done**. Apostolic Genius, the emergent phenomenon that appears when all six elements of mDNA are active and interacting, is not something we need to import from outside. It is latent within you, within your community, within every gathering of believers that takes Jesus seriously. We have, quite simply, forgotten how to access it.

This is a course of remembering, not merely learning.

## The Six Elements

Each week of the course will focus on one element of mDNA. Here is the map:

**Jesus Is Lord** — The heart and foundation. The confession that restructures all of life around the person and work of Jesus Christ. Not a slogan, but a worldview in three words. Everything else flows from this center.

**Disciple-Making** — The essential practice. Movements grow in direct proportion to their capacity to form people who look like Jesus. Discipleship is the church's primary commission — and evangelism happens within it, not alongside it.

**Missional-Incarnational Impulse** — The twin movement of going out (mission) and going deep (incarnation). Like the two blades of a pair of scissors, these impulses work together: one extends the gospel into new contexts, the other embeds it deeply into culture.

**APEST Culture** — The fivefold intelligence Christ has given to the whole body: Apostle, Prophet, Evangelist, Shepherd, Teacher. When all five are active, the church matures toward the fullness of Christ. When some are exiled, the body runs on less than all its cylinders.

**Organic Systems** — Movemental structures. Simple, reproducible, networked patterns that enable multiplication. Think farmer, not CEO. Think seed, tree, forest — not factory, product, distribution.

**Communitas** — The extraordinary community that forms when people share a liminal experience — a threshold, a risk, a mission that stretches them beyond comfort. Not community as we normally conceive it, but the deep bond forged in shared adventure.

After exploring each element, we will spend a week on **integration and system integrity** — because the power of mDNA is in the whole, not the parts. The weakest element limits the entire system, and our task is to identify and strengthen that limiting factor.

## How This Course Works: Formation, Not Information

Let me be direct about the philosophy behind this course. We have designed every element to serve **formation** — lasting change in how you see, decide, and act. This means several things:

**You will encounter dissonance.** Some of what we explore will challenge your assumptions about church, leadership, and mission. That discomfort is not a bug — it is a feature. Formation requires a willingness to stand in threshold spaces where old frameworks are being questioned and new ones are not yet fully formed. The early church thrived in precisely these conditions.

**You will take action.** Each week includes field experiments — real-world, observable practices in your own context. You will map your neighborhood, have specific conversations, test patterns in your community, and bring back evidence of what you experienced. Content serves practice in this course, not the other way around.

**You will reflect.** After each action and each reading, you will engage with structured reflection questions that help you process what you are learning and connect it to your life. Doing without reflection is activity, not formation. We pair them intentionally.

**You will journey in community.** You are part of a cohort. Each week includes discussion prompts and cohort sessions structured around Explore, Evaluate, Employ, and Journal. The people walking this path alongside you are not incidental — they are essential. Transformation is sustained and deepened in relationship.

## Your Baseline and Personalized Pathway

This week, you will take a **baseline mDNA assessment**. This is not a test — it is a diagnostic. It will help you identify which of the six elements is strongest in your context and which is your **limiting factor** — the element that, if strengthened, would have the most significant impact on the whole system.

Your results will shape a personalized pathway through the course. While everyone engages with every element, the assessment helps you know where to press in hardest, where your growth edge lies, and what to watch for as we journey together.

We will revisit this assessment at mid-course (Week 4) and at the close (Week 8) so you can see how your understanding and practice have grown. The goal is not a perfect score. The goal is movement — tangible, visible, Spirit-empowered movement toward the fullness of what God has placed within you and your community.

## How to Succeed in This Course

Three commitments will determine whether this course changes you:

**Show up consistently.** Each week builds on the previous one. The framework is cumulative and systemic — skip a week and you lose the thread that connects the elements into a whole.

**Do the experiments.** Reading about mission is not mission. The field experiments are where formation actually happens. They are designed to be achievable (one to two hours) and observable (you bring back evidence of what you did and what you noticed). Do them.

**Engage your cohort.** Post your reflections. Respond to others. Share what you are discovering. The course is designed so that your formation is deepened by the formation of those around you. We become comrades on a shared journey — and that is closer to the New Testament pattern than any solo learning experience.

## The Journey Ahead

The early Christians did not have seminary degrees, church buildings, denominational structures, or professional clergy. What they had was a simple confession — Jesus is Lord — and the six primal dynamics that flow from that confession. Under the power of the Spirit, those dynamics turned a handful of Jewish disciples into the most significant movement in human history.

That same genetic code is in you. It is in your church. It is in every community of believers that dares to take Jesus at his word and step into the adventure of missional faithfulness.

The future is in the womb of the present. The possibility of movement lies at the heart of every church. Our task is to remember what we have forgotten, and to activate what has been lying dormant.

Let's begin.

The mDNA assessment you have just completed is a diagnostic, not a verdict. It gives you a snapshot of where you and your context stand right now across the six elements of Missional DNA. Think of it the way a physician thinks about a health panel — not as a final judgment, but as information that shapes the path forward.

Your results will show relative strength across six areas: Jesus Is Lord, Disciple-Making, Missional-Incarnational Impulse, APEST Culture, Organic Systems, and Communitas. Each element contributes to the overall health of what we call Apostolic Genius — the emergent phenomenon that appears when all six are active and interacting in a living system.

### What Your Scores Mean

Higher scores in a given element indicate areas where your community or personal practice already carries momentum. These are not areas to neglect — they are strengths to steward and build from.

Lower scores indicate your **growth edge** — the area where intentional attention could produce the most significant change across the whole system. In living systems, the weakest element functions as a **limiting factor**, much like the shortest stave of a barrel limits how much water it can hold. Strengthening your limiting factor does not just improve one area; it raises the capacity of the entire system.

### What "Personalized Pathway" Means

As you move through the course, every week covers one mDNA element. Everyone engages with every module. But your assessment results help you know **where to lean in hardest**. When we reach the week that addresses your limiting factor, that is the week to press deeper — spend extra time with the reflection questions, give more energy to the field experiment, bring your honest questions to your cohort.

Your pathway is not a track that separates you from others. It is a lens that personalizes a shared journey. We walk the same road, but you know which terrain to pay closest attention to.

### What "Growth Edge" Means

A growth edge is not a failure. It is the frontier where the Spirit is most likely at work, precisely because it is the place where your current capacity meets a new challenge. Growth edges feel uncomfortable — and that discomfort is not a sign that something is wrong. It is a sign that formation is happening.

Over the eight weeks of this course, you will return to your assessment at two key points: mid-course (Week 4) and at the close (Week 8). Each time, you will have the opportunity to see how your understanding and practice have shifted. The goal is not to achieve a perfect score. The goal is observable movement — in your thinking, in your practice, and in the life of your community.

### Connecting Assessment to Journey

Your assessment results are the starting point of a formation journey, not its conclusion. The six elements of mDNA are a living system — they interact, reinforce, and challenge one another. As you grow in one area, you will often discover that other areas begin to shift as well. Trust the process. Trust the Spirit. And trust the community that is walking this road with you.

Take a moment now to record your results and your initial reflections. What surprised you? Where do you feel the most energy? Where do you sense resistance? Bring these observations to your cohort introduction this week.

sections._videoScript:
I want to say something at the outset that may create some productive discomfort: the Great Commission is not about evangelism. It is about disciple-making.

Now I know that claim provokes a reaction. We have so habitually used "the Great Commission" as a synonym for evangelism that the suggestion feels like heresy. But I need you to look at the text with fresh eyes: "Go and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them... and teaching them to obey everything I have commanded you." There is no overt mention of evangelism at all. The text explicitly binds us to the practices of discipleship and disciple-making. Evangelism gets done along the way, as you go about disciple-making — it happens in its proper context. Discipleship is evangelism's true context.

This matters more than you might initially think. This is not a semantic quibble — it is a strategic reorientation. Because once you grasp that the Great Commission is about formation rather than proclamation, everything changes: how you measure success, how you spend your resources, how you organize your community, and what you expect of every single person who confesses Jesus as Lord.

**[CORE TEACHING — The Strategic Nerve]**

Last week we established the center: Jesus is Lord. This week we explore the first and most direct expression of that lordship — the practice of making disciples.

I can say categorically that one of the most demonstrably identifiable aspects of catalytic movements is that they are obsessed with discipleship and disciple-making. Discipleship is factored in from beginning to end, and at every level of the organization. Take discipleship and disciple-making out of the equation, and these movements would never have been what they were.

And the formula is breathtakingly simple: no disciples, no movement. Some disciples, some movement. Many disciples — deeply formed, actively multiplying followers of Jesus — create the real basis on which movements generate and develop.

So what is discipleship? At its core, it involves the irreplaceable and lifelong task of becoming like Jesus by embodying his message as well as his interior habits. It has rightly been said that discipleship is who Jesus would be if he were you. Or perhaps: doing the same kind of things Jesus did for the same kind of reasons he did them.

This is profoundly different from what discipleship has become in many churches — a twelve-week class, a transfer of information, a curriculum completed. Jesus's approach to discipleship is based on the idea that we need to change people's behavior, and their thinking will follow. We act our way into a new way of thinking, not think our way into a new way of acting. The Western church has been trying to educate people into faithfulness for centuries, and we have produced generations of admirers of Jesus rather than followers. Admirers are hard to motivate and need to be constantly entertained. Only real followers will go the distance.

**[THE STAKES — Why This Is Life-or-Death]**

Here is why this matters at a systemic level: the quality of the church's leadership is directly proportional to the quality of its discipleship. If we fail in the area of making disciples, we should not be surprised if we fail in leadership development. If you cannot make disciples, you cannot reproduce leaders. If you cannot reproduce leaders, you cannot reproduce churches. The pipeline is sequential, and discipleship is the headwater.

Which means the crisis of leadership in the Western church is not fundamentally a leadership problem. It is a discipleship problem. We have been treating a symptom and ignoring the disease.

**[SIGNPOST — What to Watch For This Week]**

This week I want you to pay attention to several things as you work through the material.

First, notice the difference between the Hebraic and Hellenistic approaches to knowledge. One prioritizes concepts and information. The other prioritizes obedience and concrete existence. Jesus operated from the Hebraic tradition, and it changes everything about how we approach formation.

Second, pay attention to the relationship between discipleship and consumerism. I was trained as a marketer and advertiser before I came to Christ, and I have little doubt that consumerism is the single greatest rival religion to Christianity operating in Western culture today. The only antidote is deeper discipleship — becoming more and more like Jesus.

Third, notice the recurring pattern in every movement case study: when discipleship is the irreplaceable practice, movements are born. When it becomes an optional extra, movements die. The Methodists learned this. The early church catechumenate demonstrated this. The Chinese underground church proved this under extraordinary pressure.

**[CLOSE — The Defining Question]**

I want to leave you with a question that will surface throughout everything we explore this week. It is not whether you believe in discipleship. Every church leader I have ever met believes in discipleship. The question is whether you are making disciples. And the question after that is whether the disciples you are making are making disciples.

That is where movement lives. Let's go.

sections.scripture:
**Scripture:** Matthew 28:18–20

Then Jesus came to them and said, "All authority in heaven and on earth has been given to me. Therefore go and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit, and teaching them to obey everything I have commanded you. And surely I am with you always, to the very end of the age."

**Teaching:**

Notice what Jesus does not say. He does not say, "Go and hold evangelistic rallies." He does not say, "Go and build institutions." He does not say, "Go and develop programs." He says, *make disciples*. The Great Commission is not a synonym for evangelism — it is a mandate for formation. And it carries the full authority of the one who just declared that all power in heaven and on earth belongs to him. When Jesus is Lord, disciple-making is the strategic nerve of the entire operation. Every movement that has ever changed the world was driven by this practice. And every movement that lost it — no matter how impressive its buildings, budgets, or attendance — eventually declined.

**Reflection:**
1. When you hear "make disciples," what image comes to mind — a program, a relationship, or something else? Where did that image come from?
2. If the Great Commission is primarily about making disciples rather than about evangelism, how would that reframe the way your community measures its faithfulness?

**Prayer:**

Lord Jesus, you who hold all authority, you chose to change the world not through institutions or spectacles but through the patient, relentless practice of forming people who look like you. Forgive us where we have substituted programs for presence, information for formation, and events for the irreplaceable work of life-on-life discipleship. Make us makers of disciples — not admirers of you, but followers of you, and formers of followers. Amen.

sections.scripture:
**Scripture:** 1 Thessalonians 1:6–8

You became imitators of us and of the Lord, for you welcomed the message in the midst of severe suffering with the joy given by the Holy Spirit. And so you became a model to all the believers in Macedonia and Achaia. The Lord's message rang out from you not only in Macedonia and Achaia — your faith in God has become known everywhere. Therefore we do not need to say anything about it.

**Teaching:**

This is the anatomy of a discipleship chain. Paul says three extraordinary things: First, *you became imitators of us and of the Lord* — discipleship happens through embodied example, not abstract instruction. Second, *you became a model to all the believers* — those who are discipled become disciplers; the pattern reproduces itself. Third, *the Lord's message rang out from you* — the gospel spreads not through programs but through formed lives. Notice: Paul does not say, "We preached the message everywhere." He says, "Your faith has become known everywhere." The transmission medium is not proclamation — it is transformation.

This is how movements actually work. Jesus forms Paul. Paul forms the Thessalonians. The Thessalonians become a model to Macedonia and Achaia. And the message spreads — not because someone organized an evangelistic campaign, but because formed lives are contagious. The gospel is like a virus that needs a host, a carrier, to get spread around. Discipleship provides the hosts.

The uncomfortable question is whether our lives are transmitting anything worth imitating. Paul could say "follow my example, as I follow the example of Christ" without a trace of arrogance — because he meant it. He had so oriented his life around Jesus that his daily patterns, his relationships, his responses under pressure were recognizably Christlike. We are living letters whose message is constantly being read by others. The question is: what are people reading?

**Reflection:**

1. Who discipled you — not through a program, but through their embodied life? What was it about their way of being that formed you?
2. If you traced the chain of imitation backward from your own faith — who modeled it for the person who modeled it for you? And who is next in the chain after you?

lessons.title: The Chain of Imitation

sections.reading:
Discipleship is the lived response to the confession. Last week we established that Jesus is Lord — not as a doctrinal checkbox but as the organizing center of all reality. This week's question is: what does that lordship produce? The answer is disciples — people whose lives are being reshaped by the one they confess as Lord. A church that takes discipleship seriously is a church that takes Jesus and the gospel seriously. A church that does not take discipleship seriously is a church that does not take Jesus seriously. And a church that does not take Jesus seriously is not really a church at all. The confession without the formation is hollow. The formation without the confession has no center.

---

**Disciple-Making ↔ Missional-Incarnational Impulse**

Disciples are sent people. The practice of following Jesus naturally moves outward — into neighborhoods, workplaces, and the margins of society. You cannot make missionaries without first making disciples, and you cannot sustain mission without ongoing formation. When we explore the missional-incarnational impulse in Week 3, you will see that mission without discipleship burns people out, while discipleship without mission turns inward and becomes self-serving. The two are inseparable — like inhaling and exhaling in the same breath.

---

**Disciple-Making ↔ APEST Culture**

Discipleship is the soil in which the fivefold gifts take root. Apostles, prophets, evangelists, shepherds, and teachers do not emerge from leadership pipelines — they emerge from discipleship cultures where people are being formed into the fullness of Christ. When we reach Week 4, you will see that the Ephesians 4 gifts are not positions to be filled but capacities to be cultivated — and cultivation happens in the context of deep, life-on-life discipleship. If we are not making disciples, we should not wonder about the absence of apostolic, prophetic, and evangelistic function in our communities.

---

**Disciple-Making ↔ Organic Systems**

Simple, reproducible discipleship is the engine of multiplication. If the initial model is not readily reproducible by the regular, "nonprofessional" Christian, it will not multiply. Complexity is the contraceptive of movement. When we explore organic systems in Week 5, you will see that the organizational structures of movements are designed to serve the multiplication of disciples — not the other way around. Neil Cole's Life Transformation Groups multiply because they are simple enough for anyone to reproduce and demanding enough to produce genuine formation. That is the organic principle at work.

---

**Disciple-Making ↔ Communitas**

Formation happens best in the context of shared risk and mission. Disciple-making is not a classroom exercise — it is a journey into liminal spaces where people discover who they are becoming by following Jesus into the unknown together. When we explore communitas in Week 6, you will see that the deepest formation happens not in safety and comfort but in the crucible of shared challenge. The early church was not formed by its programs — it was formed by its persecutions, its shared meals, its willingness to follow Jesus into dangerous places together. Discipleship creates the relational depth that makes communitas possible, and communitas creates the conditions in which discipleship accelerates.

sections.reading:
We began with a provocation: the Great Commission is not about evangelism — it is about disciple-making. We traced the definition of discipleship from its Hebraic roots through the early church catechumenate, through Wesley's classes and bands, through the Chinese underground church and Neil Cole's Life Transformation Groups. We named the enemy — consumerism as a rival religion — and identified the only antidote: becoming more and more like Jesus through the irreplaceable, life-on-life practice of formation.

The central insight is strategic: movements grow only in proportion to their capacity to make disciples. No disciples, no movement. The quality of leadership flows from the quality of discipleship. The pipeline is sequential, and discipleship is the headwater.

## Commitment

Before you move on, I want to ask you to make a concrete commitment. Not a vague intention. Not "I should probably think about discipleship more." A specific, named, time-bound action:

- **Who** will you begin investing in this week — not teaching at, but forming alongside?
- **What** practice will you adopt — even if it is as simple as an LTG with one other person?
- **What** will you stop doing — what consumption will you trade for formation?

Write it down. Tell someone. Let the chain of imitation extend one more link.

## Blessing

May the Lord who chose to change the world through the patient, relentless practice of forming ordinary people into his likeness give you the courage to do the same. May you be not merely an admirer of Jesus but a follower — and a former of followers. May the chain that began with Jesus and ran through Paul and Timothy and faithful people across twenty centuries extend through you to someone who does not yet know how much they need it. And may you discover, as every movement maker before you has discovered, that there is no shortcut to this work and no substitute for it — and no greater privilege in the world. Amen.

sections.reading:
Discipleship has been so reduced in the Western church that we need to rebuild the concept from the ground up.

At its core, discipleship involves the irreplaceable and lifelong task of becoming like Jesus by embodying his message as well as his interior habits. It is our heartfelt response to Jesus as Lord and Savior. It involves our deepest commitments to allow his life to infuse ours and ours to be drawn up into his — what Paul calls "in Christ" union, and what John calls "abiding." Christ being formed in you, and you being formed in Christ.

It has rightly been said that discipleship is who Jesus would be if he were you. Or perhaps: doing the same kind of things Jesus did for the same kind of reasons he did them.

This is profoundly different from what discipleship has become in many churches — a twelve-week class, a transfer of information, a curriculum completed. The Hebraic understanding of knowledge, the one Jesus operated from, is not primarily concerned with concepts and ideas (that is the Greek philosophical tradition). The Hebraic understanding is concerned with concrete existence, obedience, life-oriented wisdom, and the interrelationship of all things under God. Jesus's approach to discipleship is based on the idea that we need to change people's *behavior*, and their thinking will follow. We act our way into a new way of thinking, not think our way into a new way of acting.

This is why the institutional church's default approach — classroom teaching, passive consumption, intellectual assent — has produced generations of admirers of Jesus rather than followers. Admirers are hard to motivate and need to be constantly entertained. Only real followers will go the distance and make a lasting impact on the world.

---

## The Discipleship-First Reframe

Here is the reframe that changes everything: if we fail in discipleship, the whole thing fails. There is no doubt — discipleship is a critical and strategic issue. The quality of the church's leadership is directly proportional to the quality of its discipleship. If we fail in the area of making disciples, we should not be surprised if we fail in leadership development. Discipleship is primary; leadership is always secondary.

This means that the crisis of leadership in the Western church is not fundamentally a leadership problem — it is a discipleship problem. If you cannot make disciples, you cannot reproduce leaders. If you cannot reproduce leaders, you cannot reproduce churches. The pipeline is sequential, and discipleship is the headwater.

Consider the Methodist movement. John Wesley's genius was not primarily organizational — it was discipleship-structural. His classes and bands, his insistence on accountability and holiness, his expectation that every Methodist would be in a formational relationship — these were the engine of the movement. When, in the mid-1800s, Methodism in America traded circuit riders (lay people with rudimentary training who planted churches as they traveled) for seminary-trained professionals, the movement's stunning growth turned into trended decline. It has never recovered. The critical "movement killers" were introduced when discipleship became an optional extra rather than the foundational practice.

The early church catechumenate tells the same story from the positive side. In the church from around AD 100 to AD 300, seekers had to prove their adherence to Jesus and commitment to his Way before they were even allowed to hear the gospel, be baptized, and join the community. Catechumens were thoroughly assessed and then put through a rigorous discipleship process by a sponsor who would take them under his wing. These catechisms could go up to four years. The result? A movement that grew from 25,000 to 20 million in two centuries — not through mass evangelism but through deep, costly, life-on-life formation.

---

## Practical Application: The Anti-Consumerist Discipline

We cannot talk about discipleship in the West without naming the elephant in the room: consumerism. I was trained as a marketer and advertiser before I came to Christ, and when I look at the power of consumerism in our lives, I have little doubt that it is the single greatest rival religion to Christianity operating in Western culture today.

The church growth movement, for all its contributions, taught us how to market and tailor the church to suit target audiences. By failing to intentionally focus on making disciples, we inadvertently cultivated religious consumerism. People became consumers of religious goods and services rather than disciples being formed into the image of Christ. The challenge is that the church is forced to compete with other invitations for our allegiance, and in the end can become just another vendor — with Jesus as the product and the Sunday service as the shopping experience.

I believe the only way to challenge the insidiously idolatrous nature of consumerism is through becoming more and more like Jesus — in other words, through discipleship. There is no programmatic solution. There is no marketing fix. The answer is the ancient one: a community obsessed with forming people who embody the way of Jesus in every dimension of their lives.

The practical implications are concrete:

**Lower the bar of how church is done and raise the bar of what it means to be a disciple.** This phrase, which I borrow from Neil Cole, captures the essential strategic shift. Stop making church attendance the measure of faithfulness. Start making Christlikeness the measure. Simplify your ecclesiology. Intensify your discipleship.

**Act your way into a new way of thinking.** Stop waiting for people to understand before they obey. At Forge Mission Training Network, we built our entire system around action-learning discipleship — placing interns in environments of mission where the vast majority of their learning comes from "having a go." The classroom follows the field, not the other way around.

**Build multiplication into the DNA from the start.** A disciple who does not make disciples is an incomplete disciple. The pattern is Paul's: "Follow my example, as I follow the example of Christ" (1 Corinthians 11:1). This creates a chain of imitation — Jesus to Paul to Timothy to faithful people who can teach others also. Every link in the chain is both a disciple and a disciple-maker.

---

## Case Studies: Where Discipleship Creates Movement

### The Chinese Underground Church — Forced Simplicity

When the Chinese church was stripped of professional clergy, institutional structures, and theological libraries, something remarkable emerged: ordinary believers began to disciple one another with extraordinary effectiveness. They had no curriculum except the gospel. They had no method except life-on-life obedience. And they multiplied at a rate that shames every resource-rich Western church model. The pattern is unmistakable: when discipleship becomes the irreplaceable practice — not an optional program — movements are born.

### Neil Cole's Life Transformation Groups

Church Multiplication Associates developed a disarmingly simple discipleship system: groups of two or three who read large portions of Scripture together, confess sin, and hold one another accountable. No trained leader required. No building required. No budget required. Just the Word, the Spirit, and mutual submission. The result? Over 10,000 churches in a decade, in sixteen countries. The system works because it is simple enough for anyone to reproduce and demanding enough to produce genuine formation.

### The Willow Creek REVEAL Study

Thankfully, the church growth movement has begun a serious self-assessment. Willow Creek's REVEAL study was a watershed moment: one of the most successful attractional churches in history looked at itself and said, "We're good at getting decisions for Christ, but not so great at making disciples." This honest reckoning represents the beginning of a critical correction — the recognition that attendance, programs, and production quality cannot substitute for the irreplaceable, life-on-life practice of forming followers of Jesus.

---

## Integration: Disciple-Making and the mDNA System

Disciple-making is perhaps the most critical element in the mDNA mix, because it involves the task of becoming more like our Founder, Jesus — of actually embodying what he was about. If we fail at this point, we are almost guaranteed to fail in all the others.

**Disciple-Making ↔ Jesus Is Lord:** Discipleship is the lived response to the confession. A church that takes discipleship seriously is a church that takes Jesus and the gospel seriously. A church that does not take discipleship seriously is a church that does not take Jesus seriously. And a church that does not take Jesus seriously is not really a church at all.

**Disciple-Making ↔ Missional-Incarnational Impulse:** Disciples are sent people. The practice of following Jesus naturally moves outward — into neighborhoods, workplaces, and the margins of society. You cannot make missionaries without first making disciples, and you cannot sustain mission without ongoing formation.

**Disciple-Making ↔ APEST Culture:** Discipleship is the soil in which the fivefold gifts take root. Apostles, prophets, evangelists, shepherds, and teachers do not emerge from leadership pipelines — they emerge from discipleship cultures where people are being formed into the fullness of Christ.

**Disciple-Making ↔ Organic Systems:** Simple, reproducible discipleship is the engine of multiplication. If the initial model is not readily reproducible by the regular, "nonprofessional" Christian, it will not multiply. Complexity is the contraceptive of movement.

**Disciple-Making ↔ Communitas:** Formation happens best in the context of shared risk and mission. Disciple-making is not a classroom exercise — it is a journey into liminal spaces where people discover who they are becoming by following Jesus into the unknown together.

---

## Conclusion: The Church That Jesus Built

The church that takes discipleship seriously is the church that Jesus built — and it is the only church that changes the world. Not the church with the biggest building. Not the church with the best music. Not the church with the most programs or the largest budget. The church that forms people who look like Jesus, and sends them to form others who look like Jesus, in an unbroken chain of imitation that stretches from the first century to the twenty-first.

Disciple-making lies at the core of the church's mission; it is not an optional extra. It is not a committee responsibility. It is not something we outsource to a curriculum or a class. It is the irreplaceable, life-on-life, community-embedded, Spirit-empowered practice of becoming more like Jesus and helping others do the same.

Next week, we explore the twin dynamic that takes discipleship into the world: the missional-incarnational impulse — going out and going deep. Because disciples are not formed in isolation. They are formed on the road, in the neighborhood, in the thick of incarnational engagement with the world Jesus came to redeem.

The question is not whether you believe in discipleship. The question is whether you are making disciples. And the question after that is whether the disciples you are making are making disciples.

That is where movement lives.

## Exercise 3: Identify Your Chain

**Instructions:**

sections._videoScript:
There is a question that has haunted the Western church for decades, and it is this: why, with all of our resources — the best buildings, the best music, the most talented communicators, the most sophisticated programs — why are we not reaching our culture? Why is the church in the West in sustained decline while the church in the global South, often with none of these advantages, is growing explosively?

I believe the answer lies in a single word: sending. Or rather, the absence of it. The dominant model of church in the West is attractional — come to us, on our terms, in our building, at our scheduled time. And that model works for people who are already culturally adjacent to the church. But it has a fatal structural flaw: it does not reach anyone else. And in an increasingly post-Christian culture, "anyone else" is becoming almost everyone.

**[CORE TEACHING — The Twin Impulse]**

This week we explore what I call the missional-incarnational impulse — and I was deliberate in combining those two words. They are like the opposing blades of a pair of scissors. The missional impulse describes the outward movement of the church as a sent people — how the gospel is "sneezed" into the world and grows virally as it extends over time and space. The incarnational impulse describes how the gospel is embedded deeply into a culture — how it takes root in the soil of a specific place, a specific people, and grows in ways that make sense within that context.

Together they result in both multiplication and transformation. Separate them and you get either superficial expansion or insular depth — but never movement.

This is not a strategy. It is rooted in the deepest theology of the faith. The missional impulse takes its cue from the Missio Dei — the mission of God. The incarnational impulse takes its cue from the incarnation of the Son of God. When God decided to reach his world, he did not send a memo. He did not launch a program. He moved into the neighborhood. The Word became flesh and blood and took up residence among us. If that is how God reaches the world, then that is how we must reach the world.

**[THE STAKES — What the Attractional Model Costs]**

Here is what the attractional model has cost us: within three to five years of a person becoming a Christian, they have no meaningful relationships with anyone outside the church. We have extracted people from the relational networks through which the gospel travels. We have turned the salt into a salt block — packed together, concentrated, impressive in our quantity — when Jesus called us to be salt shakers, embedded in the meal, bringing out the God-flavors of the earth.

Each church is a pod of seeds, pregnant with other churches. By insisting people come to us and seeking to control the mission environment, we lock up the power of multiplication. We suppress the sneeze.

**[PRACTICAL SIGNPOST — What This Week Demands]**

This week I want you to think about three practices that structure the incarnational life: proximity, frequency, and spontaneity.

Proximity means being physically present where people are — not commuting to mission but living it. Frequency means showing up often enough for trust to develop. And spontaneity means creating enough margin in your life for the unplanned encounter, the unexpected conversation, the Holy Spirit's interruption of your schedule.

Embracing proximity, frequency, and spontaneity is nothing less than integrating mission into the natural rhythms of everyday life. And I want to be clear: this does not require a budget. It does not require a building. It does not require a program. It requires a willingness to go where people are and stay long enough for something real to happen.

**[CLOSE — The Sending]**

Jesus said to his disciples, "As the Father has sent me, I am sending you." The Greek word is *kathos* — "in the same manner." Not just "go." But "go the way I went." Into the neighborhood. Into the culture. Into the mess and beauty and pain of the world.

That is the impulse. Let's explore what it means to live it.

sections.scripture:
**Scripture:** John 20:21

Again Jesus said, "Peace be with you! As the Father has sent me, I am sending you."

**Teaching:**

The Greek word here is *kathos* — "just as," "in the same manner." Jesus is not merely saying, "I am sending you." He is saying, *I am sending you in the same way the Father sent me.* And how did the Father send the Son? Not with a megaphone from a safe distance. Not with a marketing campaign. Not with an attractional event. The Father sent the Son into the neighborhood — into the mess, the complexity, the bodily reality of human existence. The Eternal moved into the neighborhood and took up residence among us. God's central method of reaching his world was incarnation. And Jesus tells his followers: your method must mirror mine. This is not a suggestion. It is a commission rooted in the deepest theology of the faith. If the Lord of all things chose to engage the world by entering it — by becoming one of us, by eating and drinking and sweating and dying among us — then we, his people, must follow in his footsteps. We must become incarnation-al.

**Reflection:**
1. When you hear "I am sending you in the same way the Father sent me," what does that demand of your current posture — are you going out, or are you waiting for people to come to you?
2. What would it mean for your community to take the *kathos* seriously — to mirror the manner of Jesus's sending, not just its content?

**Prayer:**

Lord Jesus, you who left the glory of heaven to move into our neighborhood, who ate with sinners and touched lepers and wept at gravesides — send us the way the Father sent you. Not from a distance. Not through programs. Not with control. But in the flesh, in proximity, in the messy, relational, incarnational work of embedding your presence in every corner of the world you came to redeem. Give us the courage to go out and the humility to go deep. Amen.

lessons.title: As the Father Sent Me, So I Send You

sections.scripture:
**Scripture:** John 1:14

The Word became flesh and made his dwelling among us. We have seen his glory, the glory of the one and only Son, who came from the Father, full of grace and truth.

**Teaching:**

Eugene Peterson renders this verse with devastating simplicity: "The Word became flesh and blood, and moved into the neighborhood." That single image — God moving into the neighborhood — contains the entire logic of incarnational mission. God did not send a message. He did not broadcast from a distance. He did not establish a headquarters and invite the world to come to him. He relocated. He took up residence. He entered the daily rhythms of a particular place — eating, drinking, working, sweating, celebrating, grieving — and from within that embeddedness, he revealed the glory of God.

This is the pattern that qualifies everything we do. The incarnation is not merely a doctrine to be believed — it is a method to be followed. If God's central way of reaching his world was to incarnate himself in Jesus, then our way of reaching the world should likewise be incarnational. Our method must mirror God's method.

Notice the comprehensiveness: the Word became flesh. Not spirit. Not idea. Not principle. Flesh. The incarnation dignifies the material, the local, the bodily, the particular. God did not come as a general truth for all humanity. He came as a specific person in a specific neighborhood at a specific time. And that particularity is precisely what made the revelation universal. The most incarnational thing you can do is not to be everywhere in general. It is to be somewhere in particular — deeply, faithfully, and for the long haul.

**Reflection:**

1. What would it mean for you to "move into the neighborhood" — not necessarily by relocating, but by reorienting your presence, your time, and your attention toward the people and places where God is already at work?
2. Where in your life have you been broadcasting from a distance rather than embedding yourself in the daily rhythms of the people you are called to reach?

If Jesus is Lord of all — not just the religious sector — then his people must go to all sectors. The missional-incarnational impulse is the logical extension of the lordship confession into every domain of culture, geography, and human experience. A domesticated lordship — one confined to Sundays and sacred spaces — produces an attractional church that waits for the world to come to it. A comprehensive lordship — one that reaches into every corner of creation — produces a sent church that goes where Jesus goes. The question Christology asks is: who is Jesus? The answer mission gives is: he is the one who moved into the neighborhood. And so must we.

---

**Missional-Incarnational Impulse ↔ Disciple-Making**

You cannot make missionaries without first making disciples, and you cannot sustain mission without ongoing formation. These two elements are like inhaling and exhaling — mission without discipleship burns people out, while discipleship without mission turns inward and becomes self-serving. Last week we established that a disciple is someone who is becoming more like Jesus. This week we add: Jesus is a sent person. A disciple who is not sent is an incomplete disciple. The incarnational impulse depends entirely on having people who are being formed deeply enough to carry the gospel into unfamiliar territory without losing their center.

---

**Missional-Incarnational Impulse ↔ APEST Culture**

The fivefold gifts are the functional expressions of the missional-incarnational impulse. Apostles pioneer new missional territory — they extend the gospel into unreached contexts. Prophets speak God's truth into the cultural realities that incarnational presence reveals. Evangelists draw people to Jesus in relational, incarnational settings — not through programs but through contagious lives. Shepherds nurture the communities that form around incarnational presence. Teachers ground the mission in the story of God so that contextual engagement does not drift into cultural captivity. Without APEST, the impulse has no differentiated workforce. Without the impulse, APEST has no mission to serve.

---

**Missional-Incarnational Impulse ↔ Organic Systems**

Each church is a pod of seeds, each church pregnant with other churches. The missional-incarnational impulse is the mechanism by which the seeds are scattered — it is the wind that carries them into new soil. But seeds need organic, reproducible structures to take root. Without organic systems, the impulse has no vehicle for multiplication. Without the impulse, organic systems have no energy, no direction, no reason to reproduce. The two are inseparable: the impulse provides the sending; organic systems provide the scalable form.

---

**Missional-Incarnational Impulse ↔ Communitas**

Incarnational mission is inherently liminal. When a community moves into a neighborhood, shares risk, enters unfamiliar cultural territory, and faces the unknown together, communitas is the natural result — the deepest form of bonding that occurs when people follow Jesus into danger together. The missional-incarnational impulse creates the conditions for communitas, and communitas provides the relational depth that sustains incarnational mission over the long haul. You cannot sustain presence in difficult places without the deep bonds that form when people share the journey. And you cannot form those bonds without going somewhere together.

- **Who** will you know by name that you do not know yet?
- **What** rhythm of proximity, frequency, and spontaneity will you build into the structure of your week?

The incarnational life is not a burst of missionary enthusiasm. It is a sustained reorientation of how you inhabit the world. Name it. Commit to it. Tell someone.

## Blessing

May the God who moved into the neighborhood give you the courage to do the same. May you go out with the confidence of the sent and go deep with the patience of the incarnate. May you find Christ already at work in the places you feared to enter, and may your presence there become a sign that the kingdom has come near. May the salt be scattered, the seeds be carried, and the sneeze not be suppressed. In the name of the one who left glory for a Nazarene workshop — and never regretted it. Amen.

sections.reading:
Let me define the two impulses more precisely.

The missional impulse describes the outward-bound movement that urges the church to reach beyond itself to its immediate neighbors, often across cultures and class, and eventually to the whole world. It is how the gospel is "sneezed" into the world and grows exponentially — in a viral way — as it extends itself over time and space. It is the recognition, as the great missiologists have taught us, that it is not so much that the church has a mission as that the mission has a church. We are the result of God's missionary activity in the world. God sends his Son into the world. The Son sends the Spirit into the world. The Spirit sends the church into the world. There is a sending in the heart of God that we are caught up into.

The incarnational impulse describes how the gospel is embedded deeply into a culture. As the seed of the gospel falls on cultural soil, it takes root, and Christianity develops within that culture in ways that make sense within that culture. It is how Christianity is contextualized into cultures and subcultures anywhere and everywhere. If missional defines our being sent out into the world, then incarnational must define the way in which we engage the world.

When the missional-incarnational impulse is placed alongside the other elements of mDNA at the epicenter of the church's self-understanding, it maintains the movemental impulse to partner with God in his redemption of the world. It creates the internal pressure outward into mission and downward into culture in incarnational engagement.

---

## The Incarnational Method: God Moved into the Neighborhood

When we talk of the Incarnation with a capital "I," we refer to that act of sublime love and humility whereby God takes it upon himself to enter into the depths of human existence so that reconciliation between God and humanity may be brought about. When God came into our world in and through Jesus, the Eternal moved into the neighborhood and took up residence among us. As Eugene Peterson so beautifully translates John 1:14: "The Word became flesh and blood, and moved into the neighborhood."

The incarnation not only qualifies God's acts in the world but must also qualify ours. If God's central way of reaching his world was to incarnate himself in Jesus, then our way of reaching the world should likewise be incarnational.

I have found it helpful to think about incarnational engagement through what I call the six dimensions — or "six Ps" — of incarnational practice:

**Presence.** The fact that God was in the Nazarene neighborhood for thirty years and no one noticed should be profoundly disturbing to our assumptions about ministry. Jesus was present before he was public. If relationship is the key means in the transfer of the gospel, then we are our messages, and we cannot take ourselves out of the equation.

**Proximity.** Jesus mixed with people from every level of society. He ate with Pharisees as well as tax collectors and prostitutes. Christians need to be in direct proximity to the host community, rather than expecting the community to move toward them.

**Prevenience.** God does not limit his presence to baptized Christians — he is an unrelenting evangelist. He is always at work in his world, right in the thick of things, in sinful people's lives, including our own. Our task is to discern where God is already moving and join him there.

**Powerlessness.** In seeking to act in a Christlike way, we cannot rely on normal forms of power to communicate the gospel but must take Jesus's model of servanthood. God takes the form of a servant and not that of someone who rules over us.

**Passion.** This involves us personally in what my wife, Debra, calls "the incarnation of the heart" — a genuine love for the people and place where we are sent. Surely, loving a city requires that we feel its pain.

**Proclamation.** The gospel invitation initiated in the ministry of Jesus remains alive and active to this very day. But proclamation flows from presence, proximity, and relationship — not the other way around.

---

## The Attractional Failure

Here is where the dissonance needs to land: the dominant model of church in the West is not missional-incarnational. It is attractional. And the attractional model, for all its contributions, has a fatal structural flaw: it assumes people will come to us.

The attractional-evangelistic approach is effective within a narrow cultural distance — people who are already culturally adjacent to the church. But it fails beyond that range. The net effect of using attractional evangelism only is to unwittingly block the movement of God. We know from research that within three to five years of a person becoming a Christian, they will have no meaningful relationships with anyone outside the church. Attractional evangelism in missionary contexts results in extracting people from their previous relationships and cultural context. This is a big no-no if we are serious about initiating movements. The gospel travels along relational lines. Sever the relationships and we effectively stop the outward movement of the gospel into the broader culture.

The church growth movement taught us how to pack more people into buildings through better programming, better music, better marketing. But it did not teach us how to seed the gospel into every subculture and neighborhood. We became salt blocks — packed together, impressive in our concentration — when Jesus called us to be salt shakers, embedded in the meal, bringing out the God-flavors of the earth.

Each unit of church can be conceived as a pod of seeds, each church pregnant with other churches. By insisting people come to us and seeking to control the mission environment, we lock up the power of multiplication. We suppress the "sneeze" by holding back the impulse to sneeze in the first place. To frustrate this impulse is to block the church's innate reproductive capacity.

---

## Practical Application: Proximity, Frequency, Spontaneity

The incarnational life is structured around three core practices that are disarmingly simple and profoundly demanding:

**Proximity.** Christians need to be in direct proximity to the host community. This may mean relocating. It may mean rethinking where you spend your time. It may mean — as InnerCHANGE's John Hayes discovered — that driving down to poor neighborhoods and moving into them are two very different propositions. Hayes had been driving in and out of people's lives for years, so he found an apartment and moved into the neighborhood — Minnie Street, Santa Ana, Orange County, California. His community now commits to spending eighty percent of their time in the local neighborhood.

**Frequency.** Proximity locates you among people, but frequency builds the familiarity needed for authentic relationships. When I lived in Melbourne, I regularly took Ruby, my beloved boxer, for walks throughout the local area and subsequently developed a number of relationships with other dog owners. We would stop and chat while our dogs played and sniffed one another. It was ordinary. It was repeatable. And it was the relational soil in which incarnational mission grew.

**Spontaneity.** Genuine relationships develop informally through unplanned and impromptu connections. But by definition, spontaneity does not occur without making space for it. If your calendar is so structured that there is no margin for the unexpected encounter, you have designed incarnation out of your life.

Embracing proximity, frequency, and spontaneity is nothing less than integrating mission into the natural rhythms of everyday life. It does not require a budget. It does not require a building. It requires a willingness to go where people are and stay long enough for trust to develop.

---

## Case Studies: Where the Impulse Takes Root

### InnerCHANGE — Relocation as Mission

When John Hayes moved into Minnie Street, he was making a theological statement with his address. His community of InnerCHANGE has since spread across multiple countries, always with the same commitment: incarnational presence among the poor. They do not commute to mission. They live it. The distinction is everything.

### Lance Ford's Monday Night Football

Lance Ford in Louisville tried something absurdly simple: he created flyers inviting neighborhood men to watch Monday Night Football at his house. Six guys showed up. They kept coming for six years. One man named Jeff eventually came to faith through another friend — but told Lance: "Your family had spoken volumes to him by the way we lived." Jeff pointed to the time Ford's family collected funds to repair a single mother's air-conditioning system, how they helped his family when his wife had a baby, and the fact that Lance had always treated him as a friend though he was far from Christ. No evangelistic presentation produced that transformation. Incarnational presence did.

### Theology at the Bottleworks

A group from Journey Church in St. Louis approached Schlafly Bottleworks brewery to host "Theology at the Bottleworks" — monthly discussions on poverty, global warming, race relations. They were vilified for not sharing the "gospel message" and heavily criticized for "having church where beer is served." But they understood something their critics did not: the incarnational impulse moves the gospel into the spaces where people actually live, not the spaces where Christians are comfortable.

---

## Integration: The Missional-Incarnational Impulse and the mDNA System

**Missional-Incarnational Impulse ↔ Jesus Is Lord:** If Jesus is Lord of all — not just the religious sector — then his people must go to all sectors. The missional-incarnational impulse is the logical extension of the lordship confession into every domain of culture and geography. A domesticated lordship produces an attractional church. A comprehensive lordship produces a sent church.

**Missional-Incarnational Impulse ↔ Disciple-Making:** You cannot make missionaries without first making disciples, and you cannot sustain mission without ongoing formation. Disciples are sent people. The practice of following Jesus naturally moves outward — into neighborhoods, workplaces, and the margins of society. Mission without discipleship burns people out. Discipleship without mission turns inward.

**Missional-Incarnational Impulse ↔ APEST Culture:** The fivefold gifts are the functional expressions of the missional-incarnational impulse. Apostles pioneer new missional territory. Prophets speak God's truth into cultural contexts. Evangelists draw people to Jesus in incarnational settings. Shepherds nurture the community that forms around incarnational presence. Teachers ground the mission in the story of God.

**Missional-Incarnational Impulse ↔ Organic Systems:** The pod-of-seeds metaphor is organic: each church is pregnant with other churches. Missional-incarnational engagement is the mechanism by which the seeds are scattered. Without organic, reproducible structures, the impulse has no vehicle. Without the impulse, the structures have no energy.

**Missional-Incarnational Impulse ↔ Communitas:** Incarnational mission is inherently liminal. When a community moves into a neighborhood, shares risk, enters unfamiliar cultural territory, and faces the unknown together, communitas is the natural result. The missional-incarnational impulse creates the conditions for the deepest form of community — not around shared comfort, but around shared mission.

---

## Conclusion: The Church That Goes

The church that Jesus built is not a church that waits for the world to come to it. It is a church that goes — out into the neighborhoods, deep into the cultures, across the boundaries that the institutional church has drawn around itself for protection. It goes because God goes. It incarnates because God incarnated. It enters the mess, the complexity, the beauty, and the pain of the world because that is exactly what Jesus did.

The question is not whether your community believes in mission. Every church I have ever encountered believes in mission — they have a missions committee to prove it. The question is whether your community is structured around the missional-incarnational impulse — whether going out and going deep is in your DNA, in your rhythms, in the daily patterns of how you live. Because if it is not, you are a salt block. And the world does not come to the salt. The salt goes to the meal.

That is the impulse. That is the sending. And that is how movements change the world.

sections.reflection:
1. The reading argues that the dominant church model in the West is attractional rather than missional-incarnational. Honestly assess your own community: is your primary energy directed toward getting people to come to you, or toward going to where people are? What evidence supports your answer?

2. "Christology determines missiology determines ecclesiology." What happens when you reverse the order — when you start with the church (its preferences, traditions, comfort) and try to squeeze mission into those forms? Where do you see this reversal operating in your context?

3. Consider the six dimensions of incarnational engagement: presence, proximity, prevenience, powerlessness, passion, proclamation. Which comes most naturally to you? Which is most foreign? What does that gap reveal about your assumptions about how the gospel travels?

4. The reading states that within three to five years of becoming a Christian, most people have no meaningful relationships with anyone outside the church. Is this true in your experience? If so, what structural forces produce this extraction — and what would it take to reverse it?

5. Think about the metaphor of salt block versus salt shaker. Where has your community become a concentrated block of salt, impressive but inaccessible? What would it look like to be scattered — embedded in the meal rather than piled in a container?

6. The practices of proximity, frequency, and spontaneity are described as "integrating mission into the natural rhythms of everyday life." Map your current weekly rhythms: how much time do you spend in proximity to people who do not follow Jesus? How frequent are those encounters? How much margin exists for spontaneous relational connection?

7. John Hayes moved from driving into poor neighborhoods to living in one. What is the equivalent move for your context — the difference between commuting to mission and incarnating it? What would it cost?

8. The reading says "the mission has a church" rather than "the church has a mission." How does that inversion change the way you think about your community's identity and purpose?

**Purpose:** To practice incarnational presence in a space you do not control.

**Instructions:**

Identify a "third place" in your neighborhood — not your home (first place) and not your workplace (second place), but a place where people gather informally: a coffee shop, a pub, a park, a gym, a barbershop, a community center. Commit to showing up at this place at the same time, at least three times this week.

Do not go with an agenda. Do not bring tracts. Do not organize anything. Simply be present. Notice who else is there regularly. Learn their names. Ask about their lives. Listen more than you speak. The goal is proximity and frequency — the two conditions under which genuine relationship develops.

This is what incarnational mission looks like in its most basic form: showing up, staying, and paying attention.

**Output:** A brief journal entry after each visit (2–3 sentences) noting who you encountered, what you noticed, and what surprised you. Bring these to your cohort conversation.

---

## Exercise 3: Reverse the Megaphone

**Purpose:** To practice the incarnational discipline of listening before speaking.

**Instructions:**

Choose one person in your life who is far from the faith — someone you might instinctively think of as a "target" for evangelism. This week, reverse the megaphone. Instead of preparing what you want to say to them about Jesus, prepare to listen. Ask them: What gives your life meaning? What are you most afraid of? What do you wish were different about the world?

Listen without correcting, without spiritualizing, without steering toward a gospel presentation. Simply hear them. Exegete their world the way you would exegete a biblical text — with curiosity, care, and the assumption that God is already at work in their story before you arrived.

We tend to exegete Scripture well while failing miserably at exegeting the culture in which we are immersed. This exercise corrects that imbalance.

**Output:** A one-paragraph summary of what you heard — not what you wanted to say, but what you learned by listening. Share with your cohort.

sections._videoScript:
How many times do you think the word "pastor" — shepherd — is used in the New Testament to describe people in ministry? Given how universal the term is, you would expect dozens of occurrences. The answer is completely astonishing: once. One time. Here, in Ephesians 4. And yet we have built the entire Western church's ministry architecture around this single word while systematically deleting the other four ministry types that appear alongside it in the same sentence.

If that does not create some productive dissonance, I am not sure what will.

**[CORE TEACHING — The Five]**

This week we explore what I call APEST — apostle, prophet, evangelist, shepherd, teacher — the fivefold ministry system that Paul describes in Ephesians 4 as Christ's gift to the church. And I want to be clear about the scope of this text. Paul says in verse 7, "To each one of us grace has been given." The Greek word is *hekasto* — it means every single person. This is not about a leadership elite. Every believer carries one of these five vocational intelligences, gifted by the ascended Christ, for the maturation of the whole body.

The purpose is stated explicitly: to equip God's people for works of service, so that the body of Christ may be built up until we all reach unity in the faith and become mature — attaining to the whole measure of the fullness of Christ. That is the goal. Not organizational efficiency. Not numerical growth. The fullness of Christ.

Now here is the diagnosis: the Christendom church has been run on a largely shepherd-teacher model for over sixteen centuries. By effectively exiling the apostolic, prophetic, and evangelistic ministries, we have meddled with the very mechanism Jesus intended for us to be a fully functioning body. And I want to be direct about this: as far as we can discern, it is simply not possible to be the church that Jesus intended if three of the five constitutional ministries are removed. According to the explicit teaching of Ephesians 4, it cannot be done.

**[THE METAPHOR — Procrustes]**

There is a figure in Greek mythology named Procrustes who kept a house by the side of the road. He would invite travelers in for a meal and a night's rest in his special bed. But once the guest fell asleep, Procrustes went to work — stretching the guest on a rack if he was too short, or chopping off his legs if he was too long. This is what we have done with ministry. Having exiled three of the five types and defined ministry according to the remaining two, we have forced everyone into a bed that was never designed to fit them. The apostolically gifted person is told to sit still and teach. The prophet is told to keep the uncomfortable questions to herself. The evangelist is asked to calm down and join a committee. And then we wonder why the church lacks missional energy.

**[THE STAKES — Why This Matters]**

Every observable, highly transformative apostolic movement has operated with some expression of fivefold ministry. Every single one. The Chinese underground church did it organically — under persecution, all five types emerged and functioned without anyone designing a leadership pipeline. Conversely, every movement that suppressed the full fivefold has stagnated.

We are perfectly designed to achieve what we are currently achieving. If the Western church is producing pastoral care and theological education but not pioneering mission, prophetic challenge, or evangelistic recruitment, that is not a failure of effort. It is a failure of design. We are running on two cylinders and wondering why the engine does not perform.

**[SIGNPOST — What to Watch For]**

This week, I want you to pay attention to three things.

First, notice the Christological basis. Each of the five APEST types is rooted in a dimension of Christ's own ministry. Jesus is the archetypal apostle, prophet, evangelist, shepherd, and teacher. To suppress any of the five is to suppress a dimension of Christ's presence in the world.

Second, notice what happens when any single type dominates. Pastoral monoculture produces risk-aversion. Teaching monoculture produces intellectualism. The answer is not finding the right dominant type — it is the system. All five, in dynamic relationship.

Third, and this is the hope in the diagnosis: the seed is already planted. All five types are already present in your community. The question is whether your culture, your language, your structures allow all five to function.

**[CLOSE — The Recovery]**

We are at the midpoint of this course. And I believe APEST is the hinge on which everything turns. Without the fivefold, you cannot sustain the missional-incarnational impulse. Without it, discipleship lacks the full spectrum of Christ's ministry. Without it, organic systems have no differentiated workforce. Without it, communitas lacks the creative friction that produces depth.

It is time to recover the full system. Let's explore what that looks like.
