sections.scripture:
**Scripture:** Ephesians 4:7, 11–13

But to each one of us grace has been given as Christ apportioned it... So Christ himself gave the apostles, the prophets, the evangelists, the pastors and teachers, to equip his people for works of service, so that the body of Christ may be built up until we all reach unity in the faith and in the knowledge of the Son of God and become mature, attaining to the whole measure of the fullness of Christ.

**Teaching:**

Notice the scope of verse 7: to *each one of us.* The Greek is *hekasto* — it literally means "to each and every person." Paul is not describing a leadership hierarchy. He is describing a distributed system in which every believer carries one of five vocational intelligences gifted by the ascended Christ. And notice the goal: not efficiency, not attendance, not organizational success — but *maturity,* *the whole measure of the fullness of Christ.* APEST exists for one purpose: to bring the body to the full stature of Jesus.

Now ask yourself: what happens when a body amputates three of its five limbs? Because that is precisely what the Western church has done. By effectively exiling the apostolic, prophetic, and evangelistic ministries, we have meddled with the very mechanism Jesus intended for us to be a fully functioning ecclesia. We have forced all ministry to fit into the predetermined formats of shepherd and teacher — and then wondered why the body is not reaching maturity. We are perfectly designed to achieve what we are currently achieving. And if what we are currently achieving is a church that can care and instruct but cannot pioneer, challenge, or recruit, then we have a design problem — and the design problem is that we have deleted three-fifths of the system Christ gave us.

**Reflection:**
1. If APEST is given to *every* believer, not just leaders, what does that imply about the people sitting in your community who have never been told they carry an apostolic, prophetic, or evangelistic calling?
2. Where in your context do you see the consequences of running the church on only two of the five ministry types?

**Prayer:**

Lord Jesus, you ascended and gave gifts to your church — not two, but five. You designed us for fullness, not reduction. Forgive us where we have exiled the apostolic, silenced the prophetic, and sidelined the evangelistic. Forgive us where we have forced your people into a bed that does not fit them and cut off what did not conform. Restore to us the full measure of what you gave. Make us a body that runs on all five cylinders — for your glory and for the maturation of your people. Amen.

lessons.title: To Each One of Us: The Five Gifts Are for Everyone

sections.scripture:
**Scripture:** Ephesians 4:11–16

So Christ himself gave the apostles, the prophets, the evangelists, the pastors and teachers, to equip his people for works of service, so that the body of Christ may be built up until we all reach unity in the faith and in the knowledge of the Son of God and become mature, attaining to the whole measure of the fullness of Christ.

Then we will no longer be infants, tossed back and forth by the waves, and blown here and there by every wind of teaching and by the cunning and craftiness of deceitful scheming. Instead, speaking the truth in love, we will grow to become in every respect the mature body of him who is the head, that is, Christ. From him the whole body, joined and held together by every supporting ligament, grows and builds itself up in love, as each part does its work.

**Teaching:**

Read this passage slowly and notice the movement: from Christ's giving (v. 11) through equipping and building up (v. 12) toward a destination — maturity, the whole measure of the fullness of Christ (v. 13). This is not a description of church programming. It is a vision of the church becoming what it was designed to be — a fully mature body that represents the fullness of Jesus in the world.

Now notice the mechanism: "as each part does its work." Not some parts. Each part. The apostolic parts. The prophetic parts. The evangelistic parts. The shepherding parts. The teaching parts. When any part is suppressed, silenced, or exiled, the body cannot grow to maturity. It is like a body trying to function after amputation — it can compensate, it can adapt, but it can never reach its full capacity.

The text is weighty precisely because Paul intended it to be weighty. The language, grammar, theme, and proposed outcomes all indicate the sheer importance of what is being said. This is constitutional language. And the constitution has been violated for most of church history.

**Reflection:**

1. As you read this passage, which of the five ministry types do you recognize in yourself? Which feels most foreign to you — and what does that gap tell you about the culture that formed you?

sections.reading:
The Ephesians 4 typology — the fivefold ministry that we call APEST: apostle, prophet, evangelist, shepherd, and teacher — is a major piece of Pauline ecclesiology. Markus Barth calls this section of Ephesians "the Constitution of the Church" and considers verses 11 and 12 to be the means of operationalizing it. This is not a minor text. This is not a peripheral teaching. This is constitutional.

The structure of the passage resists arbitrary selection or reduction among the five. The verbs for "given" in verses 7 and 11 are aorist indicatives — adamant verbs with no room for subtle reinterpretation. All five APEST ministries come together under the power of the ruling verb. We cannot eliminate or downplay one of these ministries without undermining the legitimacy, significance, and vitality of the others.

And the scope is universal. Paul says in verse 7, "But to each one of us grace was given." *Hekasto* — literally, "to each and every person." This means that every believer fits into the APEST typology. This is a deeply radicalizing text. APEST is not about a leadership elite. It is about the ministry of all believers. It is a part of the DNA of all God's people, making it a universal feature of all communities in Christ.

Here is how the five function:

**The apostle** is tasked with the overall vigor and extension of Christianity as a whole, primarily through direct mission and church planting. As the name itself suggests, it is the quintessentially missional ministry — "sentness" is written into it. *Apostello* means "sent one."

**The prophet** is called to maintain faithfulness to God among the people of God. Prophets are essentially guardians of the covenant relationship — they ask the uncomfortable questions about whether we are being true to who God called us to be.

**The evangelist** is the recruiter to the cause, the naturally infectious person who is able to enlist people into the movement by transmitting the gospel.

**The shepherd** (pastor) is called to nurture spiritual development, maintain communal health, and engender loving community among the people of God.

**The teacher** mediates wisdom and understanding, bringing comprehensive knowledge of the revelation bequeathed to the church.

All five are dimensions of Christ's own ministry. Is Jesus an apostle? The sent one? Yes, clearly he is the archetypal apostle. Is he a prophet? Yes, and the greatest one. Is he the evangelist of evangelists? Yes. Shepherd? He calls himself that. Teacher? Of course. Jesus parses out the core elements of his ministry into five distinct categories and plants those ministries deep within the church. What we have here is the "root-in-ization" of charisma — the ministries of APEST are rooted in, and consequently extend, the original ministry of Christ.

Anything less than a fivefold ministry is a misrepresentation of the ministry of Christ. And by consequence, it leads to a misrepresentation of Christ in the world.

---

## The Exile of the APEs

Here is where the dissonance must land. The Christendom church has been run on a largely shepherd-teacher model, and because it has had a privileged position in society, it has been inclined to dispense with the more missional ministry types — apostle, prophet, and evangelist. By effectively exiling the APE types, we have meddled with the very mechanism Jesus intended for us to be a fully functioning ecclesia. The result is that all ministry has been forced to fit into the predetermined formats of shepherd and teacher, pastor and theologian, and nothing else has legitimacy.

I want to use a metaphor from Greek mythology to describe what we have done. Procrustes was a villain who kept a house by the side of the road where he offered hospitality to passing strangers. The guests were invited in for a pleasant meal and a night's rest in his very special bed. But as soon as the guest fell asleep, Procrustes went to work — stretching the guest on a rack if he was too short for the bed, or chopping off his legs if he was too long. We have done this with ministry. Having exiled the APE types and having defined ministry according to the remaining two types, we have effectively practiced Procrustean theology — forcing everyone into a bed that was never designed to fit them.

Calvin himself — a brilliant theologian — made the fateful decision explicit. He argued that apostles, prophets, and evangelists "were not established in the church as permanent ones, but only for that time during which churches were to be erected where none existed before." With one theological stroke, three-fifths of the church's constitutional ministry was declared temporary and dispensable. And we have been living with the consequences ever since.

The result is a Sisyphean futility. Every time we seem to develop some semblance of movement and get the missional boulder up the hill, it rolls back down again. We wonder why. We try harder. We develop better strategies. But we never question the system itself — the system that runs on two cylinders and expects the performance of five.

---

## Practical Application: What Each APEST Dysfunction Looks Like

When any single APEST type dominates to the exclusion of the others, the result is predictably dysfunctional:

When **apostolic** leadership dominates, the organization will tend to be hard-driving, autocratic, with lots of pressure for change and development, leaving wounded people in its wake.

When **prophetic** leadership dominates, the organization will be one-dimensional, likely factious and sectarian, always critiquing but rarely building.

When **evangelistic** leadership dominates, the organization will have an obsession with numerical growth — counting decisions but not making disciples.

When **pastoral** leadership monopolizes — which is the default in most Western churches — the community will tend to be risk-averse, codependent, and needy, prioritizing comfort over mission.

When **teachers** rule, the church will be ideological, controlling, and moralistic — long on information but short on transformation.

The answer is not to find the right single type. The answer is the system. The elegant solution is all five, in dynamic relationship, checking and balancing one another, each contributing what the others cannot provide. Culture eats strategy for breakfast — and the culture we need is an APEST culture, not a pastoral-teaching monoculture.

---

## Case Studies: Where APEST Creates Movement

### The Chinese Underground Church — Full-Spectrum Ministry

When the Chinese church was stripped of its institutions, its seminaries, and its professional clergy, something remarkable happened: all five ministry types emerged organically. Ordinary believers functioned apostolically — pioneering new expressions of church in hostile territory. Prophetic voices called the community to faithfulness under persecution. Evangelists recruited new believers through relational networks. Shepherds cared for communities under extraordinary duress. Teachers passed on the faith through oral tradition and memorized Scripture. No one had read Ephesians 4 in a seminary classroom. But the genetic code activated under pressure.

### Mike Breen — From Megachurch to Multiplication

Mike Breen was leading one of the largest churches in England when God seemed to show him a different vision: not growth through addition — packing more people into worship services — but growth through multiplication — reproducing disciples who reproduce missional communities who reproduce churches. That shift was fundamentally an APEST shift. Breen moved from a shepherd-teacher model of ministry to an apostolic model, and the result was a movement that spanned continents.

### Hirsch's Own Leadership Team at SMRC

When I reconstructed our leadership team at South Melbourne Restoration Community around the APEST principle, the difference was immediate. We ensured that all five ministries were represented on the team, each heading up a corresponding ministry area. On any given issue, the apostolic person would present in light of the missional vision, the prophet would challenge everything and ask irritating questions about how God fit into the matter, the evangelist emphasized the need to bring people to faith, the shepherd raised concerns about people's wellbeing, and the teacher discerned the theological implications. The friction was sometimes intense — but the outcomes were incomparably richer than anything a monoculture leadership team could produce.

---

## Integration: APEST and the mDNA System

**APEST ↔ Jesus Is Lord:** APEST is the Christological ministry system. Each of the five is rooted in a dimension of Christ's own ministry. To suppress any of the five is to suppress an aspect of Christ's presence in the world. A full confession of Jesus's lordship demands a full expression of his ministry through his people.

**APEST ↔ Disciple-Making:** Discipleship is the soil in which the fivefold gifts take root. Apostles, prophets, evangelists, shepherds, and teachers do not emerge from leadership pipelines — they emerge from discipleship cultures where people are being formed into the fullness of Christ. If we are not making disciples, we will not discover or develop the full range of APEST callings.

**APEST ↔ Missional-Incarnational Impulse:** The fivefold gifts are the functional workforce of the missional-incarnational impulse. Apostles pioneer new territory. Prophets speak truth into cultural contexts. Evangelists draw people to Jesus relationally. Shepherds nurture incarnational communities. Teachers ground the mission in theological depth. Without APEST, the impulse has no differentiated capacity.

**APEST ↔ Organic Systems:** APEST is an organic, distributed system — not a hierarchical org chart. When we explore organic systems next week, you will see that the APEST model is inherently scalable: it works in a house church of twelve and in a network of thousands, because it is built into the DNA of every believer, not concentrated in professional clergy.

**APEST ↔ Communitas:** The dynamic tension between the five types creates the conditions for communitas — the deep bonding that occurs when different people with different gifts face shared challenges together. A team that includes all five APEST types will experience more conflict, more creative friction, and ultimately deeper community than a team of like-minded shepherds.

---

## Conclusion: The Seed Already Planted

Here is the good news buried in this diagnosis: the seed is already planted. All five APEST types are already present in your community, by virtue of Christ's word. They are the latent genetic code of the system. The focus should not be on trying to generate the seed — it is on creating environments that will allow it to flourish. The apostles are in your pews, wondering why no one will let them pioneer. The prophets are in your small groups, suppressing the uncomfortable questions they feel compelled to ask. The evangelists are in your neighborhoods, naturally drawing people toward the good news, wondering why the church only values their gifts during outreach week.

The question is not whether your community has all five types. It does. The question is whether your culture — your language, your structures, your expectations, your definitions of legitimate ministry — allows all five to function. Because if your vocabulary of ministry only includes shepherd and teacher, then the apostles, prophets, and evangelists in your midst have been edited out of the story. And a body that runs on two cylinders when it was designed for five will never reach the destination Christ intended.

It is time to recover the full system. Not as an addition to what you are already doing. As a correction of what has been missing.

sections._videoScript:
Let me tell you about two organisms: the spider and the starfish. A spider has a centralized brain. Cut off the head and the whole thing dies. A starfish has no head. Its major organs are replicated throughout every arm. Cut a starfish in half and you do not get a dead starfish — you get two starfish. The Western church has been organized as a spider. Movements are organized as starfish.

That is the simplest way I can state the structural challenge we face this week.

**[CORE TEACHING — The Logic of Life]**

Over centuries, the church has been taken captive to an institutional way of organizing. When we think of church, we think of buildings, clergy, denominational templates, professional staff. But this is not how the original church manifested itself. *Ecclesia* is movement. We have allowed this word to mean something profoundly different from what it originally meant.

The images Jesus uses for the kingdom are overwhelmingly organic: seeds, vines, yeast, trees, fields, bodies. These are not decorative metaphors. They are operational descriptions. When Jesus says "the kingdom of God is like a mustard seed," he is telling us how the kingdom actually works — from the inside out, through distributed life, through the logic of growth rather than the logic of control.

An organic systems approach seeks to structure the common life of the church around the rhythms and structures that mirror life itself. Every group of God's people has everything within them needed to adapt and thrive in any setting. The question is whether our structures release that potential or suppress it.

**[THE DIAGNOSIS — Complexity as Contraceptive]**

Here is the uncomfortable truth: complex attractional approaches have a contraceptive effect on the reproductive capacities of the church. It is extremely hard to reproduce a megachurch, precisely because the model depends on large buildings, charismatic leaders, large staff, and financial resources that ordinary people simply cannot replicate. The net effect is to marginalize most people from ministry and stifle genuine people movements.

Movements thrive on simplicity, reproducibility, and scalability. If the initial model is not readily reproducible by the regular, nonprofessional Christian, then it will not be magically reproducible by them later. You must build multiplication into the DNA from the start.

Every seed has the full potential for a tree, and the tree the full potential of a forest. Every church — every believer — has the full potential of a movement. The question is whether we plant seeds or build monuments.

**[CASE STUDIES — The Evidence]**

The Chinese underground church is the most dramatic illustration. When everything institutional was stripped away — buildings, clergy, seminaries, organizational structures — what remained was the irreducible DNA of the faith, distributed across millions of ordinary believers. And it multiplied from two million to over 120 million in sixty years. That is not addition. That is multiplication.

Early American Methodism tells the same story. Circuit riders — passionate lay disciples with rudimentary training — rode from town to town, planting churches as they went. Within decades, thirty percent of the American population was being discipled. Then the Methodists made a fateful decision: they required circuit riders to complete four years of seminary. The starfish became a spider. Methodism has never recovered.

The pattern is unmistakable: when you simplify, decentralize, and distribute the DNA, movements multiply. When you centralize, professionalize, and complexify, movements stall.

**[SIGNPOST — What to Watch For]**

This week I want you to think about your own context through the organic lens. Is your community structured more like a spider or a starfish? Is your model reproducible by ordinary believers, or does it depend on professionals and resources that most people do not have? Are you adding or multiplying?

And perhaps the most important question: what would it look like to think like a farmer rather than a CEO? To scatter seeds and trust the soil? To keep it simple enough that anyone can do it?

**[CLOSE — The Seed]**

Jesus said the kingdom is like a man who scatters seed on the ground. Night and day, whether he sleeps or gets up, the seed sprouts and grows — though he does not know how. All by itself, the soil produces grain.

All by itself. That is the promise of organic systems. The life is in the seed. Our job is not to manufacture the growth. Our job is to scatter the seed and keep the structures simple enough for the life to flow.

Let's explore what that means.

**Scripture:** Mark 4:26–29

He also said, "This is what the kingdom of God is like. A man scatters seed on the ground. Night and day, whether he sleeps or gets up, the seed sprouts and grows, though he does not know how. All by itself the soil produces grain — first the stalk, then the head, then the full kernel in the head. As soon as the grain is ripe, he puts the sickle to it, because the harvest has come."

**Teaching:**

Notice what the farmer does not do. He does not manufacture the seed. He does not engineer the growth. He does not stay awake at night pulling the stalks upward. He scatters. He sleeps. And the soil produces grain — *all by itself.* The Greek word is *automatos* — from which we get "automatic." The kingdom operates by the logic of life, not the logic of machines. When Jesus says "the kingdom of God is like," he is not offering a nice metaphor. He is describing operational principles. The kingdom grows organically — from the inside out, seed to stalk to head to full kernel.

This has massive implications for how we structure the church. The institutional church has operated primarily from a machine metaphor — input, output, efficiency, control. But the images Jesus and the New Testament writers use are overwhelmingly organic: seeds, vines, bodies, yeast, trees, fields. These are not decorative. They are instructive. They tell us that the kingdom does not grow through centralized control but through distributed life. Structure cannot create life, but without it life cannot exist very long. The question is whether our structures serve the life — or smother it.

**Reflection:**
1. Where in your community's life do you see the machine metaphor at work — the assumption that more control produces more growth? What has been the fruit of that assumption?
2. What would it look like to think like a farmer rather than a CEO — to scatter and trust, rather than engineer and control?

**Prayer:**

Lord of the harvest, you who scatter seed with reckless generosity and trust the soil to do its work — forgive us where we have replaced your organic logic with our mechanical control. Teach us to think like farmers, not engineers. Give us the courage to plant simple, reproducible seeds and the faith to sleep while they grow. Remind us that the kingdom does not need our management — it needs our obedience. And when the harvest comes, let it be your harvest, not ours. Amen.

sections.scripture:
**Scripture:** Matthew 13:31–33

He told them another parable: "The kingdom of heaven is like a mustard seed, which a man took and planted in his field. Though it is the smallest of all seeds, yet when it grows, it is the largest of garden plants and becomes a tree, so that the birds come and perch in its branches."

He told them still another parable: "The kingdom of heaven is like yeast that a woman took and mixed into about sixty pounds of flour until it worked all through the dough."

**Teaching:**

Two parables. Two organic images. And the same structural principle: the kingdom does not grow through impressive beginnings but through the distributed, invisible, relentless logic of life.

The mustard seed is notable for its smallness — and for the disproportionate result that emerges from it. This is the fractal principle at work: the whole potential of the tree is contained in the seed. The whole potential of the forest is contained in the tree. Every seed has the full potential for a tree, and every tree the full potential of a forest. So too every believer has the full potential of a church, and every church the full potential of a movement. The architecture of the kingdom is not designed to impress at the beginning. It is designed to multiply.

The yeast is notable for its hiddenness — mixed into sixty pounds of flour, invisible, working from the inside. You cannot see yeast at work. You can only see its effects. This is how the gospel operates: not through centralized, visible, institutional control, but through distributed, invisible, organic transformation. The yeast does not conquer the dough from the outside. It permeates it from within.

Both images challenge the institutional imagination. We want impressive beginnings. God plants mustard seeds. We want visible control. God works like yeast. We want to build monuments. God scatters seeds.

**Reflection:**

1. Where have you been looking for the kingdom in impressive, visible, institutional forms — and missing it in the small, hidden, organic work of God?
2. If every seed has the full potential of a tree and every tree the full potential of a forest, what is the "seed" in your context — the simplest, most reproducible unit of life that contains the full DNA of the movement?

sections.reading:
We began with the question of how movements scale — and discovered that the answer looks nothing like what the Western church has built. We explored the organic logic of the kingdom, the starfish-spider contrast, the contraceptive effect of complexity, and the fractal principle that the smallest unit contains the DNA of the whole. We traced the pattern through the Chinese underground church, early Methodism, and DCFI — and found the same truth repeated: when structures are simple, decentralized, and reproducible, movements multiply. When structures are complex, centralized, and professional, movements stall.

The central insight is architectural: we do not need more programs, more buildings, or more staff. We need simpler structures that serve the life rather than smothering it. Think farmer, not CEO. Think gardener, not technician. Plant seeds, not monuments.

## Commitment

Before you move on, identify one concrete simplification:

- **What will you remove** — one structure, program, or process that has become an end in itself rather than a means to the mission?
- **What seed will you plant** — one simple, reproducible expression of community life that contains the full DNA and could multiply?
- **What control will you release** — one area where you will trust the life in the seed more than your own management?

## Blessing

May the God who designed seeds to grow while farmers sleep give you the courage to simplify, the faith to scatter, and the patience to wait. May your structures serve the life rather than replacing it. May the smallest unit of your community — two or three gathered in his name — contain the full potential of a movement. And may the kingdom grow in your midst as it has always grown: all by itself, in ways you do not understand, for the glory of the one who holds all things together. Amen.

Organic descriptions of the church abound in Scripture. Images such as body, field, yeast, seeds, trees, and vines are plentiful. These images are not simply metaphors that help us describe a theological truth — they actually indicate the way the kingdom operates. When Jesus says "the kingdom of God is like," he is describing operational principles of kingdom growth.

An organic, or living systems, approach seeks to structure the common life of an organization around the rhythms and structures that mirror life itself. In this approach we probe the nature of life and observe how living things organize themselves. From there we try to emulate as closely as possible this innate capacity of living systems to develop high levels of organization and adapt to varying conditions. This connects with the idea that every group of God's people has everything within them needed to adapt and thrive in any setting.

This is funded theologically by the doctrine of creation. The Scriptures teach that the Trinity was fully involved in the inception of the cosmos and the maintenance of all life. God is the source of all life. Christ is the organizing principle of creation. The Holy Spirit brooded over the chaos. To find a pattern of church closer to life is to find a pattern closer to how God actually designed things to work. It turns out that humble yeast has much to teach us about the inner workings of movement.

I always tell would-be church planters: do not plant churches — plant movements. Because starting a movement involves an almost completely different agenda than planting a church. And the structural difference is everything.

---

## The Starfish Principle

The most helpful structural metaphor I know comes from the contrast between the starfish and the spider. Spiders have eight legs coming out of a central body, and they have a head with eight eyes. If you chop off the spider's head, it dies. At first glance, a starfish looks similar. But the similarities end there. The starfish does not have a head, and its central body is not in charge. The major organs are replicated throughout each and every arm. If you cut the starfish in half, it will not die — you will have two starfish. A starfish is basically a network of cells, with everything it needs to reproduce spread throughout the entire body.

The Western church has been organized as a spider — centralized leadership, centralized resources, centralized control. Cut off the senior pastor, and the whole organism is in crisis. Movements, by contrast, are organized as starfish — decentralized, networked, with the DNA replicated in every part. The Chinese underground church is a starfish. The early Methodist circuit riders were starfish. The early church in the book of Acts was a starfish.

The mission of God requires the seeding and reproduction of God's people in every culture and group. Each unit of church can be conceived as a pod of seeds, each church pregnant with other churches. By insisting people come to us and seeking to control the mission environment, we lock up the power of multiplication. It seems that we suppress the "sneeze" by holding back the impulse to sneeze in the first place.

---

## The Contraceptive Effect of Complexity

Here is the diagnosis that should alarm every leader in the Western church: complex attractional approaches tend to have a contraceptive effect on the reproductive capacities of the church. They can stifle genuine people movements, because effective attractional church requires a professional concept of ministry with a lot of resources.

It is darn hard to reproduce a megachurch, precisely because the model depends on large buildings, multiple departments, charismatic leaders, large staffing, and financial resources that simply cannot be replicated by ordinary people. The net effect is to marginalize most people from ministry and stifle genuine people movements.

This is why movements thrive on simplicity, reproducibility, and scalability. If the initial model is not readily reproducible by the regular, "nonprofessional" Christian, then it will not be magically reproducible by them later. You must build multiplication into the DNA from the start. If you try to factor it in later, it is very difficult and unlikely to succeed.

Every seed has the full potential for a tree, and the tree the full potential of the forest. So too every church — indeed every believer — has the full potential of a movement in it. The question is whether the structure allows that potential to be released.

Structures are needed, but they must be simple, reproducible, and internal rather than complex, centralized, and external. Think farmer, not CEO. Think gardener, not technician.

---

## Case Studies: Where Organic Systems Create Movement

### The Chinese Underground Church — Forced Into Starfish

Around 2005, my colleague Michael Frost met with leaders of the underground church who had been smuggled out of China. They were asked what they wanted people in the West to pray for. They asked for three things: first, that they would be allowed to meet in groups of more than twenty people — they were still restricted. Second, that they could meet in purpose-built buildings rather than homes, cafes, karaoke bars, and social clubs. Third, that they could develop formal theological education institutions where they could train leaders. Mike, himself a vice president of a seminary, said that in all good conscience he could not pray for those things. He realized that in many ways the Communist state was forcing the church to be exactly what it should be — simple, decentralized, reproducible, and massively effective.

### DCFI — From Bible Study to Global Movement

DCFI had its roots in a Bible study involving young people coming to faith. The leader had become increasingly frustrated with the cultural mismatch between the church and the emerging generation. He developed what he called "an underground church model," structuring the community as a movement meeting in cells across the city. In 1980 there were twenty-five people meeting in one house church. By adopting organic, networked structures, it grew to about 2,500 believers meeting in over 125 cell groups, and eventually spread to Scotland, Brazil, Kenya, and New Zealand.

### The Methodist Trajectory — From Starfish to Spider

Early American Methodism was a starfish. Circuit riders — passionate lay disciples with rudimentary training — rode from town to town, planting churches as they went. Within decades, Methodism claimed to be discipling over thirty percent of the American population. Then came the fateful decision: under pressure from more established denominations who mocked them for not knowing Latin, Greek, and Hebrew, Methodist leadership required circuit riders to complete four years of seminary training. The starfish was reorganized as a spider. Methodism in America has never regained a positive growth pattern after that decision.

---

## Practical Application: Building Organic DNA

What does this mean practically? Several things:

**Begin with the end in mind.** Plant movements, not churches. If you want a movement, you must think of *ecclesia* beyond the idea of a single local church before you begin. Build discipleship, multiplication, and reproducibility into the initial design. Do not assume you can add it later.

**Simplify ruthlessly.** Purpose and principle, clearly understood and commonly shared, are the genetic code of any healthy organization. To the degree you hold purpose and principles in common, you can dispense with command and control. People will know how to behave in accordance with them, and they will do it in thousands of unimaginable, creative ways.

**Think fractally.** When a simple triangle multiplies on itself, a pattern emerges. The whole is made up of the recursion of the smallest part. This is the fractal principle: the same DNA that operates at the level of two people in a discipleship relationship operates at the level of a house church, a network, a city movement. If the smallest unit is healthy, the whole system will be healthy.

**Resist the institutionalizing impulse.** It seems to be one of the tragic fates of human existence that over time, organizations develop a life of their own and in some way become the cause rather than serving it. What started as a dynamic new outpouring becomes a nay-saying, political controller of human behavior. The movement-to-institution trajectory is not inevitable — but resisting it requires constant vigilance and a willingness to keep structures simple.

**Aim for multiplication, not addition.** Consider the rice on the chessboard: one kernel on the first square, doubled on each subsequent square. By the sixty-fourth square, there is more rice than the world can harvest in a thousand years. That is the power of multiplication. The church of Jesus Christ should not merely be adding. It should be multiplying. Addition can never keep up with multiplication.

---

## Integration: Organic Systems and the mDNA System

**Organic Systems ↔ Jesus Is Lord:** If Jesus is the organizing principle of creation — if "in him all things hold together" — then the church should reflect the organic logic of the creation he sustains. Institutional captivity is, at root, a lordship problem: we have allowed human systems to displace Jesus's design.

**Organic Systems ↔ Disciple-Making:** Simple, reproducible discipleship is the engine of organic multiplication. The smallest unit of the movement is the discipleship relationship. If that unit is healthy and reproducible, everything else scales. If it is complex and dependent on professionals, nothing multiplies.

**Organic Systems ↔ Missional-Incarnational Impulse:** The missional-incarnational impulse is the wind that carries the seeds. Organic systems are the seed design that allows multiplication to happen when the wind blows. The pod-of-seeds metaphor captures it: each church is pregnant with other churches, ready to be scattered into new soil.

**Organic Systems ↔ APEST Culture:** APEST is inherently organic and distributed. It is not an org chart — it is a living system embedded in the DNA of every believer. Organic structures allow the full fivefold to function at every level — from the smallest cell to the largest network.

**Organic Systems ↔ Communitas:** Organic systems create the conditions for communitas by distributing risk, responsibility, and mission across the whole body rather than concentrating it in professional leadership. When everyone is a missionary, everyone shares the adventure — and the bonds forged in shared mission are the strongest bonds the church knows.

---

## Conclusion: The Mustard Seed Architecture

Jesus compared the kingdom to a mustard seed — the smallest of seeds that becomes the largest of garden plants. The architecture of the kingdom is not impressive at the outset. It is not designed to impress. It is designed to grow. And it grows not through centralized control but through the distributed life of God flowing through simple, reproducible, organic structures.

The question for your community is whether your structures serve the life or smother it. Are you a spider or a starfish? A supertanker or a speedboat? A machine or a garden? The answer determines whether you will add or multiply. And in a world where the harvest is ripe and the workers are few, multiplication is not optional. It is the architecture of faithfulness.

sections._videoScript:
Why do soldiers who have fought together form bonds that last a lifetime — bonds deeper than anything they form in peacetime? Why do people who have survived a crisis together describe the experience as the most meaningful community they have ever known? And what does that tell us about the kind of community the church was designed to produce?

This week we explore the final element of the mDNA system — and in many ways the most provocative: communitas. Not community. Communitas. The distinction is everything.

**[CORE TEACHING — Communitas Defined]**

Communitas is the type of community that develops in the context of danger, an ordeal, or an overwhelming task. It happens when, faced with such a challenge, the participants find each other in a new and deeper way. The social bonds are strengthened and restructured. Friends become comrades. Associates become partners bound together in common cause.

The anthropologist Victor Turner discovered this dynamic in his fieldwork among African tribes. His foundational example is the initiation rite: boys are taken from the safety of the village into the bush, where they face genuine danger, disorientation, and hardship together. During this liminal period — this threshold space between what was and what will be — they develop bonds that are qualitatively different from village community. They emerge not just as individuals who know each other, but as comrades who have been forged together.

There is a direct and indissoluble link between liminality and communitas — they are two sides of the same coin. You cannot have communitas without liminality. You cannot have deep, forged-in-fire community without shared risk, shared danger, shared ordeal.

**[THE DIAGNOSIS — Pseudocommunity]**

And here is the uncomfortable implication: when we seek to build community without the experience of liminality, all we end up with is the kind of pseudocommunity that pervades many churches. It is more like a support group than a communitas.

I learned this painfully in my own ministry. The early years of the community I led in Melbourne were radically missional — exciting, focused, alive. But as the community attracted more established, middle-class Christians, something shifted. Safety replaced risk. Comfort replaced mission. And what we had was pleasant enough — but it was not communitas. We had shifted from "the community for the world" to "the community for me."

Gordon Cosby, after sixty years of remarkable ministry, observed that no groups that came together around a non-missional purpose ever became missional. Only groups that set out to be missional got around to doing it. Mission is the organizing principle of communitas. Without it, community always turns inward.

**[THE STAKES — Why This Matters]**

Equilibrium is a precursor to death. When a living system is in a state of equilibrium, it is less responsive to changes around it. The Western church is profoundly nonadaptive because it is preoccupied with safety. But some things benefit from shocks — they thrive and grow when exposed to volatility, disorder, and stressors. This is the concept of antifragility. And it describes the church at its best.

The early church was not formed by its programs. It was formed by persecution, shared meals in the shadow of empire, and the willingness to follow Jesus into dangerous places together. The Chinese underground church did not grow because it had better strategies. It grew because sustained liminality activated communitas — bonds so deep that no amount of state repression could break them.

**[SIGNPOST — What to Watch For]**

This week, pay attention to the difference between community and communitas in your own experience. Where have you experienced the deepest bonds — in comfortable settings, or in challenging ones? Where have you been most alive, most connected to others, most aware of God's presence — in safety, or on the edge?

And pay attention to the call that liminality makes on all of us: to leave the fish tank for the ocean. To move from settlers to tent dwellers. To follow Jesus not into a program but into an adventure.

**[CLOSE — Ruined for the Ordinary]**

A community in Ontario describes itself as "ruined for the ordinary." That is the fruit of communitas. Once you have experienced it, comfortable fellowship feels thin by comparison.

The question is whether you are willing to be ruined. Let's find out.

By faith Abraham, when called to go to a place he would later receive as his inheritance, obeyed and went, even though he did not know where he was going. By faith he made his home in the promised land like a stranger in a foreign country; he lived in tents, as did Isaac and Jacob, who were heirs with him of the same promise. **Teaching:**

The writer of Hebrews pictures the Christian community on earth as living like Abraham — in tents, in the land of promise, as in a foreign land. Ecclesiologist Paul Minear observed that "the church is by its very nature composed of tent dwellers." Not settlers. Not homeowners. Tent dwellers. People who are perpetually on the move, perpetually in transition, perpetually in that liminal space between promise and fulfillment, between the already and the not yet.

This is profoundly unsettling for those of us shaped by middle-class Western culture, where safety, security, comfort, and predictability are the highest values. But the most theologically fertile sections of Scripture — the patriarchal narratives, the exodus, the exile, the prophets, the Gospels, Acts — were all forged in conditions of liminality. The settled periods are precisely when Israel and the church lose faithfulness. The deepest community the church has ever known was formed not in safety but in shared danger, shared mission, and shared dependence on God.

**Reflection:**
1. Where has your community settled into safety and predictability — and what has been lost in that settling?
2. What would it mean to live as "tent dwellers" rather than settlers — people whose deepest bonds are forged in the shared journey rather than in shared comfort?

**Prayer:**

Lord of the journey, you called Abraham out of security and into the unknown, and from that liminal journey you built a people. Call us out again. Disturb our equilibrium. Break us free from the comfortable pseudocommunity we have mistaken for the real thing. Give us the courage to follow you into the dangerous, disorienting, beautiful terrain where true community — communitas — is born. We want to be tent dwellers, not settlers. Pilgrims, not consumers. Your people, on the move with you. Amen.

**Scripture:** 2 Corinthians 11:23–27

Are they servants of Christ? I am more. I have worked much harder, been in prison more frequently, been flogged more severely, and been exposed to death again and again. Five times I received from the Jews the forty lashes minus one. Three times I was beaten with rods, once I was pelted with stones, three times I was shipwrecked, I spent a night and a day in the open sea. I have been constantly on the move. I have been in danger from rivers, in danger from bandits, in danger from my fellow Jews, in danger from Gentiles; in danger in the city, in danger in the country, in danger at sea; and in danger from false believers. I have labored and toiled and have often gone without sleep; I have known hunger and thirst and have often gone without food; I have been cold and naked.

**Teaching:**

Whippings, beatings, imprisonment, and shipwrecks can hardly be called "safe, secure, comfortable, and convenient." Yet through these experiences, Paul and his apostolic band totally realigned the course of history around the gospel of Jesus Christ. This is not the resume of a comfortable community leader. This is the testimony of a man living in sustained liminality — and the communitas he formed with his companions along the way was so deep that its effects are still reverberating two thousand years later.

Paul's extraordinary courage flowed from a simple source: he had already lost his life for Jesus's sake. "For to me, to live is Christ and to die is gain." When you have truly lost your life, you are free from the loss aversion that keeps most people tethered to safety. Paul was not risk-tolerant — he was loss-free. He had nothing left to lose, and therefore everything to give.

This is the kind of life that produces communitas. Not a life organized around self-protection, but a life poured out in mission — where the danger is real, the stakes are high, and the bonds forged in the crucible are unbreakable.

**Reflection:**

1. Paul's catalogue of sufferings is also a catalogue of communitas — shared danger that produced the deepest bonds. Where in your life has suffering or risk produced the deepest relationships? What does that tell you about how community actually forms?
2. Paul says "to live is Christ and to die is gain." What would need to shift in your heart for that to move from a theological statement to a lived reality — and what would that freedom do to your capacity for communitas?

sections.reading:
Let me define the terms precisely, because precision matters here.

**Liminality** applies to the situation where people find themselves in an in-between, marginal state in relation to the surrounding society — a place that could involve significant danger and disorientation, but not necessarily so. The word comes from the Latin *limen*, meaning "threshold." It is the space between what was and what will be — the space of transition, uncertainty, and possibility.

**Communitas** is the type of community that develops in the context of danger, an ordeal, or an overwhelming task. It happens when, faced with such a challenge, the participants "find each other" in a new and deeper way. The social bonds are strengthened and restructured. Friends become comrades. Associates become partners bound together in common cause.

There is a direct and indissoluble link between liminality and communitas — they are two sides of the same coin. We cannot have one without the other. Communitas does not emerge from comfort, stability, or safety. It emerges from the shared experience of the threshold — the shared ordeal, the common challenge, the journey into the unknown undertaken together.

---

## The African Initiation Rite: The Foundational Illustration

The anthropologist Victor Turner, whose work forms the academic foundation for this element of mDNA, did his fieldwork among African tribes. His foundational illustration is the initiation rite: boys are kept under the care of women until age thirteen. At the appropriate time, men sneak into the village at night and "kidnap" the boys. They are blindfolded, roughed up, herded into the bush, circumcised, and left to fend for themselves for up to six months. Once a month, elders visit to debrief and mentor them. During this liminal period, the boys undergo a profound transformation — they move from disorientation and individualism to developing a deep bond of comradeship. If they emerge, they are reintroduced to the tribe as men.

The rite works because it is genuinely liminal — genuinely disorienting, genuinely dangerous, and genuinely shared. The community that forms in the bush is qualitatively different from the community of the village. It is communitas — bonds forged in the crucible of shared ordeal.

---

## Why the Western Church Settles for Pseudocommunity

Here is the uncomfortable truth: when we seek to build community without the experience of liminality, all we end up with is the kind of pseudocommunity that pervades many churches. It is more like a support group than a communitas.

I came to this realization through painful personal experience. The early years of the community I led at South Melbourne Restoration Community were radically missional — the community was focused, sharpened, and something wonderful was forming. But as the community became more established and attracted more middle-class Christians from the suburbs, something shifted. We became more stable, but what was most significant was inadvertently lost as the church culture changed. I came to the conclusion that there must be something about middle-class culture that works against the radical claims of faith — that safety, security, comfort, and consumerism function like bugs in the software, undermining communitas from the inside. The community shifted from "the community for the world" to "the community for me."

This is not unique to one church. It is the structural tendency of every community that prioritizes safety over mission. Gordon Cosby, the pioneering leader of Church of the Saviour in Washington, DC, observed after over sixty years of significant ministry that no groups that came together around a non-missional purpose ever became missional. Only groups that set out to be missional actually got around to doing it. Mission is the organizing principle of communitas. Without it, community turns inward and eventually becomes a vendor of relational services — competing for the attention of spiritual consumers.

---

## The Biblical Case: Liminality as Normative

Some have proposed that liminality is merely transitional — a phase the church passes through on its way to something more stable. I must say that I have not fundamentally changed my conviction: liminality and communitas are much more the normative situation and condition for the people of God.

The evidence is overwhelming. Survey the Scriptures and you will find that the most theologically fertile sections were formed in times of extremity. The patriarchs lived as tent-dwelling strangers. The exodus forged Israel's identity in the wilderness. The exile produced the prophets' deepest theology. The Gospels narrate a liminal movement led by a homeless rabbi. Acts describes a community forged in persecution. Paul's extraordinary letters were written from prison cells and shipwrecks. These are not safe little bedtime stories — they call us to a dangerous form of faithfulness.

The settled periods — the monarchy, the post-Constantinian church, the comfortable Christendom establishment — are precisely the periods when God's people lose their edge, their faithfulness, and their mission. When the people of God settled down and "forgot YHWH," the prophets had to spiritually disturb them, recalling the dangerous memories about fires on the mountain and pursuing armies. Equilibrium, it turns out, is a precursor to death. When a living system is in a state of equilibrium, it is less responsive to changes occurring around it.

---

## Practical Application: Creating Conditions for Communitas

You cannot manufacture communitas. But you can create the conditions under which it emerges. Several principles:

**Organize around mission, not ministry.** Ministry is the means by which we accomplish mission, but mission must be the organizing principle. Groups that form around shared comfort — Bible studies, fellowship dinners, affinity groups — rarely develop communitas. Groups that form around shared mission — incarnational engagement in a neighborhood, a justice initiative, a church plant in a hard place — discover communitas as a byproduct of the journey.

**Embrace the edge of chaos.** From living systems theory: the church is at its innovative best near the edge of chaos. The edge of chaos is a condition, not a location. It is a permeable, intermediate state where productive agitation runs high and innovation thrives. The Western church is profoundly nonadaptive because it is preoccupied with safety. Depriving systems of vital stressors is not a good thing. Some things benefit from shocks — they thrive and grow when exposed to volatility, randomness, disorder, and stressors.

**Put people at risk.** When we started Forge Mission Training Network, we recognized the desperate need for entrepreneurial gifting. So we developed a philosophy of education that put our interns "at risk." If they are standing within their current realm of expertise, they are only going to learn what they already know. So the learners take one step out of their comfort zone, closer to the edge of chaos, and then another half step so they are "at risk" of real failure. That risk is where formation happens.

**Cast a vision that creates liminality.** A vigorous transformative vision can itself create liminality. Holding a definite vision of the future alters how people think and behave in the present. Kennedy's moonwalk vision gathered disparate motivations into unified action. The "already and not yet" tension of the kingdom of God functions as a "strange attractor" that keeps the church moving forward. Managing from the future is one of the most powerful tools for generating the conditions of communitas.

---

## Case Studies: Where Communitas Transforms

### The Chinese Underground Church — Sustained Liminality

The Chinese underground church and the early church are the two phenomenal Jesus movements that most clearly demonstrate sustained liminality-communitas. Both experienced long-term persecution and were outlawed. Both grew explosively — not despite the danger, but through it. The bonds that formed under persecution were incomparably deeper than anything produced by comfortable church programming. This is communitas at its most powerful — not a weekend retreat, but a sustained way of life under pressure.

### Mark Scandrette's Mural Art Co-op

Mark Scandrette, an urban missionary in San Francisco, initiated a mural art co-op. The co-op gathers to paint walls throughout the city — largely non-Christian people. They secure a wall, gather as a collective to decide what to communicate, divide up sections, and spend Saturdays painting, chatting, and sharing lunch. By the end — up to three months — they have delved deeply into one another's lives and explored themes of life, God, and spirituality. The shared creative ordeal — the challenge of producing something together — created the conditions for communitas in an entirely non-religious context.

### The Fellowship of the Ring

Tolkien understood this instinctively. The Fellowship of the Ring becomes a real fellowship only as it undergoes struggle and hardship. The unlikely group — elf, dwarf, hobbits, humans, wizard — discovers one another in ways impossible in normal circumstances. In the Return of the King, the four hobbits share a long, knowing look in the pub after everything they have been through — no words can express what they are thinking, but they know each other's thoughts. This is the community found only in communitas.

---

## Integration: Communitas and the mDNA System

**Communitas ↔ Jesus Is Lord:** The confession of Jesus's lordship is itself a liminal act in a world that confesses other lords. To say "Jesus is Lord" and mean it is to step into a threshold space — marginal, countercultural, and potentially costly. Communitas is the community that forms among those who have taken that step together.

**Communitas ↔ Disciple-Making:** Formation happens best in the context of shared risk and mission. Disciple-making is not a classroom exercise — it is a journey into liminal spaces where people discover who they are becoming by following Jesus into the unknown together. The deepest discipleship happens on the edge, not in the center.

**Communitas ↔ Missional-Incarnational Impulse:** Incarnational mission is inherently liminal. When a community moves into a neighborhood, enters unfamiliar cultural territory, and faces the unknown together, communitas is the natural result. The missional-incarnational impulse creates the very conditions communitas requires.

**Communitas ↔ APEST Culture:** The dynamic tension between different APEST types creates friction — and friction, in the right context, produces communitas. A team of diverse gifts facing a shared challenge will experience deeper bonding than a homogeneous group in comfortable agreement.

**Communitas ↔ Organic Systems:** Organic systems distribute risk and mission across the whole body rather than concentrating it in professional leadership. When everyone participates in the adventure — not just consumes — communitas becomes possible at every level of the system, from the smallest cell to the largest network.

---

## Conclusion: Ruined for the Ordinary

There is a community in Uxbridge, Ontario, called the Winking Circle. It started with one family and some local kids who took over a condemned house. They customized bikes into eccentric art machines, started bands, designed clothes, organized shows, built skate ramps. Ramps were burned by vandals. Their dream ramp was sawn in half. But the community persisted — and its members were, as they say, "ruined for the ordinary."

That phrase captures the fruit of communitas: you cannot go back. Once you have experienced the depth of community that forms in the crucible of shared mission — the bonds forged when you follow Jesus into the unknown together — ordinary community feels thin by comparison. Comfortable fellowship feels like a fish tank when you have swum in the ocean.

The question is whether you are willing to leave the tank. The journey is liminal. The destination is communitas. And it is the only community that changes the world.

**Purpose:** To create the conditions under which communitas can emerge in your context.

**Instructions:**

Design one experience for your community that introduces genuine liminality — a shared challenge, risk, or threshold that moves people out of comfort and into the unknown together. It should meet these criteria:

I want to return to a story I told at the beginning of this course — the story of The Wizard of Oz. Dorothy and her companions travel to the Emerald City seeking what they believe they lack: brains, heart, courage, and a way home. After surviving dangerous encounters and overcoming the source of evil, they discover that they already had what they were looking for — they had it all along. The Scarecrow was clever all along. The Tin Man had real heart. The Lion was brave. And Dorothy had the capacity to return home in her ruby slippers from the very beginning.

This story highlights the central assumption of everything we have explored: all God's people carry within themselves the same potencies that energized the early Christian movement and the Chinese underground church. Apostolic Genius lies dormant in you, me, and every local church that seeks to follow Jesus faithfully in any time. We have simply forgotten how to access and trigger it.

The most amazing thing we learn from the Chinese experience — along with every other apostolic movement in history — is that the church Jesus started already has everything in it to get its job done. Ecclesia is perfectly designed to fulfill its mission and purpose. What is more, every believer — and by extension, every believing community of Christ — has the same full potential for world transformation present in even the smallest part. Apostolic Genius is latent within the ecclesia, and given the right conditions, it can be reactivated and can transform the church into a potent movement of the gospel.

---

## The System in Motion: How the Six Elements Interact

Let me trace the system dynamics one final time, because seeing the connections is essential to activating the whole.

**Jesus Is Lord** is not merely the first element. It is the organizing principle — the center around which the entire system orients. When the lordship of Jesus is truly confessed and lived, it creates the conditions for everything else: the urgency to make disciples, the impulse to go into the world, the recognition that all five ministry gifts are needed, the commitment to simple structures, and the willingness to face risk together.

**Disciple-Making** is the engine. Movements grow only in proportion to their capacity to make disciples. If discipleship is healthy, it produces the people who carry the mDNA into every other domain. Without disciples, there is no one to send, no one to express the fivefold gifts, no one to multiply, no one to share the liminal journey.

**The Missional-Incarnational Impulse** is the sending dynamic — the outward and downward movement that takes formed disciples into the world. It provides the direction and energy that prevent the system from turning inward.

**APEST Culture** is the ministry system — the differentiated workforce that ensures the full range of Christ's ministry is expressed through his people. Without it, the impulse has no differentiated capacity; the community cannot pioneer, challenge, recruit, care, and teach simultaneously.

**Organic Systems** provide the architecture — simple, reproducible, fractal structures that allow the movement to scale without losing its DNA. Without them, the movement has energy but no vehicle for multiplication.

**Communitas** is the relational fruit — the deep bonds forged when people follow Jesus into liminal territory together. Without it, the movement has structure but no soul, strategy but no depth.

When all six are active — when the system is functioning as an integrated whole — something qualitatively different emerges. It is not merely the sum of six good ideas. It is an emergent phenomenon: Apostolic Genius. The whole is greater than the sum of its parts.

---

## The Diagnostic: Where Is Your System?

Please note: I do not mean to suggest some sort of ecclesiological "technique" or church methodology here. Apostolic Genius is a mindset, an approach, a phenomenon, a way of thinking and doing church. There are internal checks and balances within it to keep it from degenerating into a mere technique. Commitment to Jesus's kingdom at the heart of the church — together with the willingness to become more like him — ensures the spiritual health of the movement.

But a diagnostic is still useful. For each of the six elements, assess your community honestly:

| Element | Active? | Evidence |
|---|---|---|
| **Jesus Is Lord** — Is his lordship the functional center, not just a doctrinal affirmation? | | |
| **Disciple-Making** — Are you actively forming reproducing followers of Jesus? | | |
| **Missional-Incarnational Impulse** — Are you going out and going deep into culture? | | |
| **APEST Culture** — Are all five ministry types recognized and released? | | |
| **Organic Systems** — Are your structures simple and reproducible enough to multiply? | | |
| **Communitas** — Is your community forged in shared mission, not just shared comfort? | | |

Remember: we are perfectly designed to achieve what we are currently achieving. If the outcomes are not what the New Testament envisions, the system needs adjustment — not more effort within the existing design.

---

## The Evidence: Where the System Works

The early church grew from as few as 25,000 in AD 100 to up to 20 million by AD 310 — a persecuted, illegal, marginalized movement that had no buildings, no professional clergy in the modern sense, no political power, and no cultural advantage. All six elements of mDNA were active.

The Chinese underground church grew from about 2 million to over 120 million in sixty years — stripped of institutions, seminaries, buildings, and professional leadership, under sustained persecution. All six elements of mDNA were active.

Early American Methodism discipled thirty percent of the population through circuit riders and classes — lay people with rudimentary training, operating in simple, reproducible structures, driven by the lordship of Jesus and a passion for holiness. All six elements were active. When the system was compromised — when discipleship became optional, structures became complex, and mission was replaced by institutional maintenance — the movement declined.

Church Multiplication Associates, founded by Neil Cole, saw over 10,000 churches planted in sixteen countries in a decade — through Life Transformation Groups, simple structures, and a missional-incarnational commitment. All six elements were active.

The pattern is unmistakable. When all six elements are present and functioning, movements are born. When any element is absent or suppressed, the system weakens. The question is never whether the system works. It always works. The question is whether we will activate it.

---

## The Personal Integration

This is not just about communities. It is about you. Apostolic Genius is latent in every true believer. The mDNA is in your spiritual DNA as surely as it is in the DNA of the church.

Ask yourself: Is Jesus functionally Lord of my life — of every area, not just the religious sectors? Am I actively making disciples who make disciples? Am I incarnationally present in my neighborhood and sent into the world? Do I know my APEST calling, and am I functioning in it? Is my life simple enough to be reproducible — could someone follow my pattern? Am I living in the liminal space where communitas is born, or have I retreated to safety?

The integration is not institutional. It is personal. The movement does not start with a strategy. It starts with a disciple who carries the full DNA.

---

## Conclusion: The Question That Haunts

About four years prior to writing The Forgotten Ways, I attended a seminar where the speaker asked a question that has haunted me to this day: "How do you account for the fact that a tiny, persecuted Jewish sect became the most significant religious force in the Roman Empire in two centuries?" It was as if God was calling me to dedicate myself to finding the answer.

The answer, I believe, is Apostolic Genius — the full mDNA system, activated by the Spirit, functioning in an integrated whole. It was not a strategy. It was not a program. It was a way of being the church that carried within it the potencies for exponential impact.

Those same potencies are in you. In your community. In the ecclesia of which you are a part. The ruby slippers are on your feet.

The question that remains is whether you will click them together.

sections.reflection:
1. The reading says "there are no single silver bullets — but there is a silver imagination that emerges when all six elements come together." Where have you been looking for silver bullets — a single change that would fix everything — rather than working on the whole system?

2. Look at your system map. What is the weakest element — the shortest stave of the barrel? How has that weakness affected every other element? Trace the ripple effects through the connections.

3. "Ecclesia is perfectly designed to fulfill its mission and purpose." If that is true, then the church you are part of already has everything it needs. What is preventing the activation of what is already there?

4. The Wizard of Oz story suggests we already have what we are looking for — we have simply forgotten how to access it. What has this course helped you remember? What "ruby slippers" have you been wearing all along without realizing it?

5. "Apostolic Genius is a mindset, not a technique." Where are you tempted to reduce the mDNA system to a technique — a program to implement rather than a way of being to embody?

6. Review the six elements one final time. For each, complete this sentence: "The one thing I will do differently because of what I learned about [element] is..."

7. The course has traced Apostolic Genius through the early church and the Chinese underground church. Both were persecuted, marginalized, and stripped of institutional resources — and both exploded with transformative power. What does that tell you about the relationship between adversity and activation? And what does it demand of you in a context where you are not persecuted?

8. As you prepare for the commissioning next week, name the single most important commitment you are carrying forward from this course — the one that, if you honor it, will change everything.

**Purpose:** To see the entire mDNA system as an integrated whole and to diagnose where your community's system is strong, weak, or broken.

**Instructions:**

### Part 1: Map the System (Individual)

Draw a hexagon with six points, one for each mDNA element:

1. **Jesus Is Lord** (top center)
2. **Disciple-Making** (upper right)
3. **Missional-Incarnational Impulse** (lower right)
4. **APEST Culture** (lower center)
5. **Organic Systems** (lower left)
6. **Communitas** (upper left)

Draw connecting lines between every pair of elements (15 connections total). This visual represents the dynamic, nonlinear system.

For each element, rate your community's current state from 1 (absent or nominal) to 5 (deeply embedded and functioning). Mark the rating on each point of the hexagon. Connect the ratings to form a shape.

Now look at the shape. A perfect hexagon means all six are equally active. A lopsided shape reveals where the system is imbalanced. The weakest point is your limiting factor — like the shortest stave of a barrel, it determines the maximum capacity of the whole.

### Part 2: Trace the Connections (Individual or Pairs)

For each of the 15 connecting lines, write one sentence describing how the two elements interact in your context. Where is the connection strong (both elements reinforcing each other)? Where is it broken (one element undermining or starving the other)?

Pay special attention to connections involving your weakest element. Because the system is interconnected, the absence of one element affects every element it connects to. A weakness in discipleship, for example, does not just mean fewer disciples — it means fewer people to send (missional impulse), fewer APEST gifts activated, less capacity for organic multiplication, and less relational depth for communitas.

### Part 3: The Action Plan (Group)

Bring your system map to your cohort. Compare maps. Identify common patterns — where are your communities collectively strong? Where are they collectively weak?

Then together, design a ninety-day action plan that addresses the most critical weakness. Not six initiatives for six elements. One focused intervention aimed at the element that, if strengthened, would most improve the whole system.

**Output:** Your visual system map, your connection analysis, and your ninety-day action plan. These will carry you beyond the course and into the ongoing activation of Apostolic Genius in your context.

sections._videoScript:
Eight weeks ago, I asked you a question: what if there is a power that lies hidden at the very heart of God's people — something given by Jesus, activated by the Holy Spirit, but somehow buried and lost through centuries of neglect and institutional overlay? What if the most remarkable energies that could propel Christianity well into the twenty-second century are primal forces that lie latent in every Jesus community and in every true believer?

You have spent eight weeks exploring the answer. You now carry knowledge of the six elements of mDNA — Jesus Is Lord, Disciple-Making, the Missional-Incarnational Impulse, APEST Culture, Organic Systems, and Communitas — and the emergent phenomenon of Apostolic Genius that occurs when all six are active.

But let me say what I always say at this point: knowledge is not the goal. Formation is. The question is not whether you understand the system. The question is whether the system is activating in you — in your life, in your community, in the way you inhabit the world.

**[THE HONEST RECKONING]**

Some of you are leaving this course energized and ready to act. Good. Do not waste that energy. Channel it into the ninety-day plan you designed last week. Start with the weakest element. Build from there.

Some of you are leaving overwhelmed — the gap between what you have seen and what you are currently living feels enormous. That is normal. That is the dissonance doing its work. Do not try to change everything at once. Pick one thing. The most important thing. And start there.

Some of you are leaving skeptical — wondering whether this actually works in your context, with your resources, in your culture. To you I say: the evidence is overwhelming. The early church did it with no resources. The Chinese church did it under persecution. The Methodists did it with lay people on horseback. CMA did it with groups of two and three reading Scripture together. The system works. The question is not whether it works. The question is whether we will trust it.

**[THE COMMISSION]**

You are not leaving this course as consumers of information. You are leaving as bearers of the DNA. The mDNA is in you. It has always been in you. What this course has done — I hope — is help you remember what was forgotten.

Go and make disciples. Go into the neighborhoods. Release the fivefold. Simplify the structures. Follow Jesus into the liminal spaces. And do it together — as comrades, not just acquaintances. As a movement, not just a church.

The ruby slippers are on your feet. Click them together. Go home. And change the world.

**[CLOSE]**

It has been my privilege to walk this journey with you. I believe in you — not because you are extraordinary, but because the God who designed the church is extraordinary. And the church he designed already has everything it needs.

Go in peace. Go in power. Go in the name of the one who holds all authority in heaven and on earth.
