sections.action:
We gather for the last time in this course — not to finish, but to begin. For eight weeks we have explored the DNA that Jesus planted in his church: the lordship that organizes all reality, the disciple-making that forms his people, the sending that takes them into the world, the fivefold gifts that equip them, the organic structures that multiply them, and the forged-in-fire community that sustains them.

Now we commission you. Not as experts. Not as program leaders. As bearers of the DNA — ordinary people who carry within them the same potencies that energized the early church and the Chinese underground church. The ruby slippers are on your feet.

---

### The Confession (Together)

*We confess that Jesus is Lord — not of the religious sector alone, but of all reality.*
*We confess that we are called to be disciples who make disciples — not admirers, but followers.*
*We confess that we are sent — into neighborhoods, cultures, and the margins of society.*
*We confess that we carry gifts — apostolic, prophetic, evangelistic, shepherding, teaching — given by the ascended Christ for the fullness of his body.*
*We confess that the kingdom grows organically — through seeds, not monuments.*
*We confess that we are tent dwellers — pilgrims formed by the journey, not settlers defined by the building.*

---

### The Commissioning Statements (Individual)

Each person reads aloud the commissioning statement they wrote for the final assessment. After each statement, the group responds:

**Group Response:** *Go in the name of Jesus. We send you. We hold you accountable. We pray for you.*

---

### The Charge (Facilitator)

You have been given the forgotten ways. Do not forget them again.

Make disciples. Go to where people are. Release every gift. Keep it simple. Follow Jesus into the unknown — together.

The question is not whether you believe in Apostolic Genius. The question is whether you will activate it. Not next year. Not when conditions are right. Now. With what you have. Where you are.

---

### The Blessing (Facilitator)

May the Lord who holds all authority in heaven and on earth send you with the confidence of the sent.

May the one who changed the world through patient, relentless discipleship give you the perseverance to form followers who form followers.

May the God who moved into the neighborhood give you the courage to move with him — into the places that need his presence most.

May the Christ who is apostle, prophet, evangelist, shepherd, and teacher activate the fullness of his ministry through you.

May the one who designed seeds to grow while farmers sleep give you the faith to plant and the patience to wait.

And may the Spirit who hovers over chaos and brings life from the edge give you the companionship of comrades — not just acquaintances, but fellow travelers, ruined for the ordinary, bound together in the most important mission in the world.

Go. The DNA is in you. It has always been in you.

In the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit. Amen.

---

### Closing (Facilitator)

The course is complete. The journey has begun. Stay connected. Hold each other accountable. And remember: no disciples, no movement. Some disciples, some movement. Many disciples — deeply formed, actively multiplying followers of Jesus — create the basis on which movements generate and develop.

That is where movement lives. Now go and live it.

The course is complete. The formation is not. Here is how to sustain what has been activated:

### The Ninety-Day Plan

You designed a focused action plan in Week 7. This is your primary commitment for the next three months. Review it weekly. Report to your accountability partner or cohort monthly. Adjust as needed — but do not abandon it. The temptation after a course like this is to return to the way things were. Resist that temptation. The mDNA is in you. Activation requires sustained practice, not momentary enthusiasm.

### The Cohort Connection

Stay connected with your cohort beyond the course. Agree on a simple rhythm:
- **Monthly check-in:** A thirty-minute call or meeting to report on your ninety-day plan. What happened? What is working? Where are you stuck?
- **Quarterly gathering:** A longer session (ninety minutes) to revisit the full mDNA system, share stories, and recalibrate.

The bonds formed in this course are the beginning of communitas. Do not let them dissolve into acquaintance. Sustain them with shared mission and mutual accountability.

### The Formation Companion

Your AI formation companion remains available beyond the course. Use it for:
- Processing specific challenges as you implement your ninety-day plan
- Deepening your understanding of any mDNA element
- Preparing to teach or facilitate mDNA content with your own community
- Working through the recommended reading with guided reflection

### Passing It On

A disciple who does not make disciples is an incomplete disciple. The same is true of this content. Consider:
- **Teaching the mDNA framework** to your community — not as a program, but as a shared language for understanding what the church is designed to be.
- **Starting a reading group** around The Forgotten Ways with your leadership team.
- **Recommending this course** to others who are ready for the journey.
- **Living the content** — which is, ultimately, the most powerful form of transmission. When people see Apostolic Genius activated in a real community, they do not need convincing. They want to join.

### The Final Word

The question that haunted the beginning of this course remains the question that defines its ending: How do you account for the fact that a tiny, persecuted Jewish sect became the most significant religious force in the Roman Empire in two centuries?

The answer is Apostolic Genius. The answer is mDNA. The answer is the latent potential that lies dormant in every community that confesses Jesus as Lord.

Your job is to activate it. Not next year. Now.

Go.

longDescription: The Western church has largely operated within a Christendom framework for over 1,700 years, and much of what we assume to be normative Christianity is actually the result of cultural accommodation rather than biblical faithfulness. In Reframation, Alan Hirsch argues that the church needs a fundamental reframing of its self-understanding, theology, and practice in order to recover its missional calling.

Drawing on decades of research into apostolic movements, Hirsch lays out a compelling case for why the inherited model of church -- centered on buildings, clergy, and programs -- fails to produce the kind of disciple-making movements that characterized the early church. He invites readers to reconsider the assumptions that shape how we gather, lead, and engage the world around us.

This is not a book about minor adjustments. It is a call to re-examine the very frames through which we see the church, leadership, and mission. With theological rigor and practical insight, Hirsch provides a roadmap for communities ready to move beyond institutional maintenance toward genuine missional engagement.

indexAbout.title: About Alan
indexAbout.text: Alan Hirsch is a missional theologian, author, and thought leader. He has written widely on apostolic movement, discipleship, and the renewal of the church. His work includes The Forgotten Ways, 5Q, and Reframation, and he co-founded the 5Q Collective and Movement Leaders Collective. This platform exists to translate his work—into conversation (AL), courses, books, and your language.
